DOC.HEAD: Wife of Pro-Solidarity Journalist Dies in Suspicious Fire
DOC.TEXT: The wife of a reporter who investigated the secret police for a pro-Solidarity newspaper died Sunday after leaping from the window of her burning apartment, the official PAP news agency reported. A Solidarity official alleged the fire was arson, and the government said it was investigating. The fire killed Maria Jachowicz, 49, but her husband, Jerzy, and their 14-year-old daughter jumped from an apartment window and escaped with slight injuries, the agency reported. Jerzy Jachowicz has written numerous articles for the pro-Solidarity newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza about the workings of the Interior Ministry, which controls the secret police in Poland. At Solidarity's national congress in Gdansk, delegate Michal Boni said it appeared the fire had been set by arsonists and proposed a resolution demanding an investigation into whether officers from the Interior Ministry were responsible, PAP reported. The motion was sent to a congress committee for review, the agency said. A statement from the press office of the Solidarity-led government said an ``intensive investigation is being carried out by the police'' and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki is being kept informed of its course. Earlier this month, Parliament voted to eliminate the dreaded secret police and to change the Interior Ministry into a smaller, civilian-run office. It had previously been staffed by uniformed functionaries along military lines and was considered part of the national defense system. The secret police had monitored and harassed dissidents and even ordinary citizens to maintain the Communist Party's grip on power in Poland. The new Office of State Protection is to limit its activities to fighting espionage and threats to national security. The secret police are suspected in scores of political killings and four secret police were convicted in the 1984 kidnapping and murder of pro-Solidarity priest Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko. The government has said the secret police force was reduced from 24,000 officers in June to 3,100 this year. Some reportedly took early retirement while others were permitted to transfer to the Citizens Militia after retraining.

DOC.HEAD: Truck Seized With Parts of `Iraqi Gun'
DOC.TEXT: Custom officials have seized a truck carrying seized steel tubes believed to be parts for a huge Iraqi gun for firing missiles, Turkish newspapers reported Saturday. The Istanbul daily Hurriyet quoted Finance and Customs Minister Adnan Kahveci as saying ``a massive investigation'' was under way following the seizure. The tubes, discovered Wednesday in a truck at Kapikule near the Bulgarian border, were sent to the Istanbul Technical University for examination, the newspaper said. On Friday, Greek customs officials seized a huge cylinder that it said Iraq ordered from Britain for an artillery system. Greece's move came seven days after Britain also seized a shipment of steel tubes headed for Iraq. Turkey officials questioned two people in connection with the incident, but nationalties were not given, Hurriyet said. Hurriyet said authorities believed the confiscated parts resembled those seized in England. After the Greek announcment Friday, the British company Walter Somers Ltd. said it had shipped the tubes in two trucks, one of which had been detained in Greece, the other in Turkey. Istanbul daily Cumhuriyet said the British government requested the tubes be returned, but Turkey refused it on grounds of international law. No other details were given in Turkish newspapers, and officials could not immediately be reached to elaborate on Saturday's reports. British officials seized eight steel tubes on the Middlesbrough docks in England on April 12. The tubes were parts for a gun that would be 130 feet long with a bore of nearly 40 inches, British customs officials said. The Iraqi government and the British manufacturer of the tubes, Sheffield Forgemasters, have said they were designed for a petrochemical plant. There was no immediate comment from Iraq on the Greek shipment. Weapons experts have said a gun built from the parts confiscated in Britain and Greece could fire nuclear or chemical missiles hundreds of miles, far enough to reach Israel and Iran. Britain banned arms shipments to Iran and Iraq when the two Middle Eastern countries were at war, and the ban remains in effect.

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Rebels Release Kidnapped Television Executive
DOC.TEXT: Pro-Cuban guerrillas Saturday night freed a prominent television executive was kidnapped in October in Lima, police said. Hector Delgado Parker, owner of Peru's largest television and radio network, was reported in good condition after being held more than six months by the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement. Police said Delgado Parker was released about 7:45 p.m. but details of his release were not made available and it was not known whether a ransom was paid. President Alan Garcia and Interior Minister Agustin Mantilla visited Delgado Parker at his home in the fashionable Miraflores suburb, five miles south of Lima. A videotaped message by a Tupac Amaru leader was broadcast by Delgado Parker's Chanel 5 television station Wednesday night. An announcer said the broadcast was one of the kidnappers' demands for Delgado Parker's release. The guerrilla group began fighting Peru's government in 1984. The group takes its name from an 18th century mestizo revolutionary who fought to free Peru's highlands from Spanish colonial rule. The group operates mostly in areas of Peru's northern and eastern jungle, and occasionally bombs banks, embassies and government offices in Lima.

DOC.HEAD: Actress Cathy Rigby Hit By Sword During Show
DOC.TEXT: Gymnast-actress Cathy Rigby was injured when struck in the head by a sword during a performance of ``Peter Pan.'' It took ten stitches to close the wound the former Olympic gymnast suffered during a flying sequence in the third act of the play Friday night at the Midland Theater. ``That's why, I guess, you don't play with knives,'' Rigby said in an interview Saturday before she appeared in a matinee. Rigby was suspended in the air to simulate flying during a fight with Captain Hook when her sword hit the set and struck her in the head near the temple, said Tom McCoy, her husband and producer. Rigby bled profusely from the wound, which eventually required 10 stitches, McCoy said. Rigby's head was bandaged, and she returned within a minute for the final act, he said. ``I'm sure the audience thought it was very realistic,'' Rigby said. As the blood flowed, Rigby said, she thought: ``How do we fake this one? It's not like losing a line.'' Two other characters, Cindy Robinson as Wendy and Holly Erwin as Tiger Lily, finished Peter Pan's song while Rigby's wound was quickly dressed offstage. ``It was like the Mike Tyson fight,'' McCoy said. ``We were trying to get our Peter Pan patched up for Round 15. There was blood everywhere.'' ``The audience definitely knew Peter had been in a tough fight with Captain Hook,'' McCoy said. After the show, Rigby was treated at the emergency room of St. Luke's Hospital and released.

DOC.TEXT: Erte, whose pioneering art deco designs in graphics, fashion and theater of the 1920s returned to popularity in recent years, died Saturday, a hospital spokesman said. He was 97. Erte _ whose real name was Romain de Tirtoff _ was known as a painter, sculptor, lithographer and set designer. He designed costumes for the legendary dancer Anna Pavlova and the performer-spy Mata Hari. The prolific artist designed every cover of Harper's Bazaar from 1915 to 1936. His most recent project was to design the sets for the Broadway musical ``Stardust.'' Some of his other major designs for sets and costumes included Debussy's ``Pelleas et Melisande'' and Racine's ``Phedre.'' He was also well-known for the opulent clothes and sets he designed for George White's ``Scandals,'' the Ziegfeld Follies and the Folies Bergere. ``He was just a genius,'' said Harris Shapiro, president of the Dyansen Corp. gallery chain in an interview in Los Angeles. ``I think history will reflect a few years from now that he was one of the greatest artists of the 20th century.''
DOC.HEAD: Frank Lausche
DOC.TEXT: Frank J. Lausche, a former five-term governor and U.S. senator who was one of Ohio's most unorthodox and successful politicians, died Saturday of heart complications. He was 94. Lausche lost his first two races _ for the Ohio House in 1922 and the Ohio Senate in 1924. In 1932, he was appointed judge of the Cleveland Municipal Court. In 1941, he was elected mayor of Cleveland, a post he held until his election in 1944 to the first of five terms as governor. Lausche's long political career ended in 1968 with his defeat _ due mostly to a long-running feud with organized labor _ in the Democratic primary for re-election to a third term in the U.S. Senate. He was the only Ohio governor to be elected five times. A conservative Democrat, Lausche served in the state Senate, was appointed a municipal court judge in Cleveland and was elected in 1941 mayor of that city. In 1944, he was elected to his first term as governor. Although a Democrat, Lausche earned a reputation as an independent who often ignored party positions and consistently proved popular among independents and Republican voters.
DOC.HEAD: Horst Sindermann
DOC.TEXT: Horst Sindermann, a former high-ranking East German Communist official and Parliament leader, died Friday of a heart attack, the official ADN news agency said. He was 74. Sindermann was a member of the ruling party Politburo and president of the Communist-dominated Parliament until November, when mass demonstrations toppled the hard-line leadership. The son of a Dresden book printer, Sindermann was jailed for eight months in 1933 for after joining a Communist youth group. He was convicted of high treason in 1935 and spent the next 10 years in Nazi prison camps until the end of World War II. After the victorious Allies divided Germany into East and West, Sindermann served as editor of various Communist Party publications and held regional party posts until named to the Politburo in 1967. Nine years later, he became president of Parliament and a member of the former council of state. After the demonstrations that toppled former party leader Erich Honecker, the Communist leaders who replaced him purged many members of the old guard. Sindermann was stripped of power and party membership in November.

DOC.HEAD: Volcano Lava Torches Two More Homes Saturday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS in 6 grafs to UPDATE with second home destroyed Saturday, total number of homes destroyed now at 87; pick up 6th graf pvs, `Nearly all ...'. ADDS 1 graf at end with Redoubt eruption; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Lava flowing from Kilauea Volcano swallowed two more homes Saturday, and an evacuation order was expanded in this community threatened by the long eruption. A 40-foot-wide finger of lava, which destroyed three houses in the Kalapana Gardens subdivision on Friday, set one house ablaze about 11:20 a.m. Saturday, said Lanny Nakano, a Civil Defense spokesman on Hawaii Island. Lava destroyed another home in the subdivision at 6 p.m. Saturday, said Wendell Hatada, another Civil Defense spokesman. ``As long as the eruption continues, the threat is real to the whole community,'' said Bruce Butts, another Civil Defense spokesman. An evacuation order, issued a week ago for 25 homes in the 120-house subdivison, was extended Saturday to 24 more homes, Butts said. A 24-hour alert remained in effect for about 40 other houses in outlying areas. Kilauea lava has destroyed eight homes in April, including five since Wednesday. So far, 87 homes have burned since the current eruption began in January 1983, said Butts. The volcano has caused more than $20 million in damage. Nearly all of Kilauea's daily output of 650,000 cubic yards of lava was reaching Kalapana, and the eruption showed no signs of easing, said Reggie Okamura of the U.S. Geological Survey's Hawaiian Volcano Obervatory. Meanwhile, state Insurance Director Robin Campaniano said insurance companies that cancel or fail to renew policies of homeowners in the volcano-ravaged subdivision will be subject to fines or loss of their licenses. Also on Saturday, Mount Redoubt in Alaska exploded with perhaps its smallest blast to date, sending steam and ash 25,000 feet into the air, said Geologist Steve Brantley with the Alaska Volcano Observatory. He said the eruption is significant because it is part of an unusually stable pattern.

DOC.HEAD: Hostage Mother Reports Call From State Department
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT Ina Clare Turner's hometown, Hayden sted Moscow; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The mother of Lebanon hostage Jesse ``Jon'' Turner said Saturday she was told by the U.S. State Department that Syrian officials had said a hostage would be released within 24 to 36 hours. Estelle Ronneburg said she received the call from Michael Mahoney, her liaison with the State Department, about 5 p.m. MDT saying that a hostage would be released. A State Department official who spoke on condition of anonymity told The Associated Press that Mahoney was relaying information given to U.S. officials by the Syrian foreign minister. Mahoney told Mrs. Ronnenburg the State Department had no information to contradict the report, according to the official. Mrs. Ronnenburg said the Mahoney didn't tell her which of the three prisoners would be released. ``Of course, I'm hoping it will be Jon, but if it's not, I'll be happy for the other families,'' she said. A pro-Iranian group is holding Turner, along with Robert Polhill, a business professor, and Alann Steen, a journalist, hostage. Turner was one of four Beirut University College staff members taken hostage Jan. 24, 1987. Turner, 42, an associate professor of mathematics and computer science at the Beirut campus, was abducted with three other academics, two Americans and an Indian, by men posing as police assigned to protect the college staff. He moved to Beirut from Hawaii in 1983, his mother said. Turner's Lebanese wife, gave birth to a daughter, Joanne, on July 24, 1987, five months after he was kidnapped. His first wife, Ina Clare Turner, lives in Hayden, Idaho.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Candidate Says He Paid for Prostitutes As Young Man
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Williams, who ...', to ADD Williams is campaigning as a law-and-order candidate and that prostitution is illegal in Texas, legal in parts of Mexico; pick up 8th graf, `A call ...
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial nominee Clayton Williams disclosed that he paid prostitutes for sex a number of times in Mexico and his native West Texas, a newspaper reported Sunday. He said it has been at least 35 years since he visited a prostitute and considered it a rite of passage. ``Why, of course,'' Williams, 58, told The Houston Post when asked whether he ever paid women for sex. ``It's part of growing up in West Texas ... It's like the Larry McMurtry book, `The Last Picture Show,''' the Midland rancher and oilman said. The book is about teen-age affairs in a small Texas town in 1951. Williams told the Post he first paid for sex at age 16. In addition to patronizing prostitutes as a teen-ager, Williams said he paid for sex while a student at Texas A&M University. Williams, who faces Democratic state Treasurer Ann Richards in the November gubernatorial general election and has campaigned as a law-and-order candidate, said the disclosure has no bearing on his leadership capabilities as a mature adult. Prostitution is illegal in Texas and was illegal 35 years ago; it is legal in parts of Mexico. A call by The Associated Press to the Richards campaign late Saturday was answered by a machine. The Post interviewed Williams at a posh desert resort in Scottsdale, Ariz., where he was spending the weekend for the annual meeting of the All-American Wildcatters, a fraternity of sorts for independent oilmen. The colorful millionaire, never before elected to public office, has sunk $5.6 million of his own money in an $8 million campaign. Williams came under fire from women's groups and political opponents last month when he jokingly likened bad weather to rape, saying if it was inevitable to ``just relax and enjoy it.'' The day after he made the remark, Williams apologized and said he realized his comment was ``insensitive.'' During a visit to Washington earlier last month, Williams told reporters he would feel uncomfortable running against a woman. Williams and his wife, Modesta, celebrate their 25th wedding anniversary next month. They have three children, including two adopted teen-age boys. Williams also has two children from a previous marriage. As she did when her husband faced heat for the rape remark, Modesta Williams stood by him Saturday on the subject of prostitution, the Post reported. ``What he did before we were married is certainly his business. That doesn't bother me at all,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Nigerian Officer Claims to Have Overthrown Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with officer's statement, report of gunfire; pickup graf 4 pvs `A statement...'
DOC.TEXT: A middle-ranking Nigerian officer speaking on his nation's radio claimed Sunday to have overthrown the military government of President Gen. Ibrahim Babangida. A Western diplomatic source in Paris said gunfire had been heard in Lagos. Some radio stations outside Lagos, the capital of the West African nation, appeared to be broadcasting normally, and the major's claim could not be confirmed. A man identifying himself as Maj. Gigi Oguaza Oka read a statement on National Radio in Lagos saying: ``Fellow Nigerian citizens: On behalf of the patriotic and well-meaning peoples of the middle belt and southern parts of this county, I ... wish to happily inform you of the successful ousting of the dictatorial, corrupt, drug-baronish, inhumane, sadistic, deceitful, homosexually centered and unpatriotic administration of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida.'' Babangida's military government has been viewed as heavily weighted in favor of the Moslem north since the forced retirement earlier this year of Defense Minister Lt. Gen. Domkat Bali. A statement read on the Lagos radio, which was monitored in Abidjan, called on students, workers, lawyers and shopkeepers to take to the streets to support the coup. It also said military men were confined to their bases, and an overnight curfew was being imposed. During intervals in broadcasts of martial music, the radio accused Babangida of widespread corruption and human rights violations. Babangida took power in a barracks coup on Aug. 27, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Beirut Radio Reports Steen Will Be Freed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to ADD details of radio reports on Steen being released; pickup graf 10 pvs `Earlier Saturday...'
DOC.TEXT: Beirut radio stations said U.S. hostage Alann Steen is likely to be freed from 39 months of captivity Sunday on his 51st birthday. The reports in morning newscasts said Steen, a Boston native, may be released within ``a few hours.'' Speaking on condition of anonymity, sources close to the Iranian Embassy told The Associated Press that Steen's frail health could persuade his kidnappers to end his ordeal. Steen is held by the pro-Iranian Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. On Saturday, state-run Beirut television reported pro-Iranian kidnappers would turn the freed U.S. hostage over to the U.S. ambassador in Syria. In Boise, Idaho, the mother of hostage Jesse Turner said she received a call Saturday from a State Department official, saying a hostage would be released within 24 to 36 hours. A department official confirmed the call, but said the United States was only relaying information given to it by Syrian officials and had no reason to contradict that information. Beirut television's English-language news bulletin quoted an unidentified Syrian official as saying the hostage would be ``freed sometime on Sunday, probably in the morning,'' by Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. ``The hostage will be produced at the Syrian Foreign Ministry and then handed over to U.S. Ambassador Edward Djerejian,'' said the station, which is based in Moslem west Beirut. It did not elaborate. Its sister station in Christian east Beirut later broadcast the same report, which could not be independently verified. The reports predicting Steen's release were broadcast Sunday by the prestigious Moslem-run Voice of the Nation and the Voice of the People, a communist-run station in west Beirut. Voice of the Nation said Steen will be freed ``in line with the ostentatious behavior of the hostage-holders.'' Steen suffers from chronic high blood pressure. In the early days of his captivity, the kidnappers reported he was gravely ill and near death. But he appeared on a videotape released in May 1987 and said he had recovered. Earlier Saturday, an Iranian daily that usually reflects the thinking of Iran's president urged the Lebanese kidnappers to keep their promise to free an American hostage despite their claim that Washington was delaying the release. The Tehran Times, which has repeatedly called for the release of all Western hostages in Lebanon over the last three months, said in an editorial that the release could be ``the prelude to the release of one more hostage by another group.'' Daryl Penner, spokesman for the U.S. Embassy in Damascus, stressed Saturday that Washington will not send John Kelly, Assistant Secretary of State for Near East Affairs, to negotiate the release as demanded by the kidnappers. Syrian Foreign Ministry sources, however, said the U.S. Embassy had requested and been granted permission to land a plane at Damascus airport. U.S. Embassy officials declined comment. But the sources said the plane was believed to be to fly a released hostage to Wiesbaden, West Germany. American captives released in the past have been flown to the U.S. military hospital there for medical checks and debriefing. A U.S. team flew there Thursday. Turner's mother, Estelle Ronneburg, said in Boise that she was called by Michael Mahoney, her liaison with the State Department. She said he did not specify which of the hostages would be released. Turner is one of three U.S. educators held by the pro-Iranian group and one of eight Americans held in Lebanon. A State Department official who spoke on condition of anonymity told The Associated Press that Mahoney was relaying information given to U.S. officials by the Syrian foreign minister. Mahoney told Mrs. Ronnenburg the State Department has no information to contradict the report, according to the official. White House Chief of Staff John Sununu gave no indication the Bush administration had any confirmation of a Sunday release. ``You're always hopeful, but having gone through frustrations over the years I think everybody involved in this is going to believe it only after it happens,'' Sununu told CBS News on Saturday. The captors said Wednesday they would free an American within 48 hours, and they demanded Kelly go to Damascus to finalize arrangements. But the following day the group declared the release postponed indefinitely after President Bush, citing U.S. policy not to negotiate with terrorists, refused to send Kelly to Syria. The Tehran Times, an English-language daily, said in an editorial Saturday that U.S. Ambassador Djerejian is ``good enough to conduct the arrangements for the release of the hostage.'' Djerejian has been involved in frequent talks with Syrian officials since returning to Damascus Thursday. The Iranian newspaper, which is close to President Hashemi Rafsanjani, expressed impatience with the postponement and said it hoped the freeing of one captive could be ``the prelude to the release of one more hostage by another group.'' It did not specify which pro-Iranian faction it meant by ``another group.'' There are 18 Westerners currently held in Lebanon. Rafsanjani, leader of Tehran's so-called pragmatists, has been seeking for months to free the hostages as part of his efforts to improve Iran's relations with the West after a decade of hostility. He believes that securing the release of hostages will encourage Western companies to invest in Iran to boost its limping economy and hopefully encourage Washington to release an estimated $12 billion in frozen assets. The Iranian leader is opposed by fundamentalist, anti-Western radicals in the Tehran hierarchy. An aide to Hussein Musawi, Shiite Moslem mentor of Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, said Saturday that Musawi remains sure that the group will free one of the Americans it holds. But the aide, contacted by telephone by The Associated Press, gave no indication when that might be. Musawi heads the Shiite Islamic Amal faction based in the Syrian-controlled Bekaa Valley in east Lebanon. He said Friday he believed the release will go ahead despite Washington's ``arrogant ... cowboy behavior.'' In addition to Turner, a communications professor and Steen, a journalism professor, the group holds Robert Polhill, 55, an accounting lecturer from New York. The three were kidnapped from the campus of the U.S.-affiliated Beirut University College on Jan. 24, 1987, by gunmen disguised as riot police. Also missing in Lebanon are five other Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman. The longest-held captive is Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985, and is held by another Iranian-backed Shiite faction, Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Calls for Meeting of European Bishops
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Sunday called for an unprecedented meeting of European bishops to allow the church to keep pace with the political changes sweeping the continent. He made the announcement as he visited a shrine in Moravia dedicated to Cyril and Methodius, who introduced Christianity to the Slavs 12 centuries ago. The old Communist regime barred him from visiting here in 1985. John Paul said the meeting, called a synod, will be held ``at a not too distant date.'' Papal spokesmen Joaquin Navarro said he did not expect it would be held this year. He said details will be announced in Rome on Tuesday. The synod would be the first such continent-wide summit bringing together bishops from all European countries. ``Today in this very place, we are seeing the signs of a new blessing in the promising travail of deep and vital transformations,'' said the pope, speaking from an altar at a 700-year-old basilica. He said the European bishops should have the opportunity to ``reflect more on the historic moment for Europe and the church.'' Navarro also announced the pope may visit Cuba in December. The pope had earlier accepted an invitation to visit the Caribbean island ruled by a hard-line Communist government, but no date had been set. Before the Mass, the pontiff rode through the cobblestone streets of Velehrad, in central Czechoslovakia, in his white Popemobile. Crowds chanted ``Long live the Holy Father!'' As John Paul prepared to say Mass outside the basilica, redone in Baroque style in the 17th century, a huge throng gathered. The worshipers included Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who in August became the East bloc's first non-Communist government leader. The Czechoslovak news agency CTK estimated the crowd at 200,000 to 400,000. Archbishop Frantisek Vanak of Olomouc welcomed John Paul to the altar. The archbishop referred to the pope's frustrated attempt to visit Velehrad in 1985 for a feast to celebrate 1,100 years of Christianity in Czechoslovakia. Czechoslovakia's leaders, who were then Communist, refused permission for the papal visit to this city where Cyril and Methodius introduced Christianity to the Slavs. ``This visit was preceded by years of yearning to have you, the pope, Christ's witness, here among us. This yearning was growing all the more and more as the dark forces tried to hinder it,'' Vanak said. ``But God's cause prevailed.'' The pope has made the celebration of Eastern Europe's toppling of communism a major theme of his two-day trip, which began Saturday. It is his first to the region since the dramatic changes that rocked Communist regimes last year. Until the communist regime fell, such a trip was impossible. But John Paul is also warning Eastern European countries about ``viruses'' from the West, such as secularism, hedonism and atheism. After celebrating the Mass at Velehrad, the pope was to fly 90 miles to Bratislava, the capital of Slovakia, for another open-air service. Statistics released by the Vatican estimate 10.7 million Catholics live in Czechoslovakia, out of a population of 15.6 million. The pope, who turns 70 next month, was making the 46th foreign pilgrimage of his pontificate.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He Has No Word On Hostage Release
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Sunday he has not heard ``anything new'' about reports that an American hostage was about to be released in Lebanon. The vacationing president, standing on a beach at sunrise, said, ``Since the hopes of the American people have once again been raised, I can't tell you that I've learned anything new this morning at all.'' Later, on his way to go fishing in the Florida Keys, Bush told reporters his staff was in contact with the U.S. embassy in Damascus every three minutes to keep up with the situation. ``There's no news to it, no news .... I just talked to the situation room,'' Bush told reporters shouting questions to him shortly after 8 a.m. EDT. Asked if a hostage would be released today, Bush said, ``We don't know. We're talking every three minutes to our embassy in Damascus ..., but there is no news there now.'' Bush, who rose early on Earth Day to honor an environmental group protecting Florida's coral reefs, said earlier that he didn't want to ``be a part of raising the hopes of the families and then not have something happen.'' Bush added, ``I wish I could tell you, but there isn't any news that's been brought to my attention this morning. But let's hope, because this was one of the days that's been signaled as where there might be some action.'' Asked how he would respond to a release of one of the eight American hostages in Lebanon, Bush said, ``Too hypothetical.'' ``You've got to see what happens. I'm talking about release of all the hostages.'' That is ``the bottom line,'' he said. The Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine said last Wednesday it would release a U.S. hostage within 48 hours, then postponed any release. There were widespread reports in Beirut that Alann Steen, a college teacher held for more than three years, might be released on Sunday, his 51st birthday. Bush said, ``We want every American held against his will, her will, released, wherever they may be. That's the ground rules. That's the bottom line.'' ``Let's hope there's some action,'' he added, ``but there's no point in my speculating.'' ``Put yourself in the place of these families. One day, there's a picture of one of these hostages, the very next day it's another,'' he said. ``I don't consider that a very good way to deal with the emotions and the prayers of the families, frankly, so I can't contribute any more to it.'' Bush spoke briefly with reporters on a beach in the Florida Keys after presenting one of his ``Point of Light'' awards to Reef Relief of Key West, Fla. He also used the occasion to announce a proposal to close the coral reefs off the Florida Keys to ships longer than 50 meters and all vessels carrying oil or hazardous materials. He said the United States is petitioning the International Maritime Organization to establish an ``area to be avoided'' 10 miles off the Florida coast from Key Biscayne to the Dry Tortugas. If granted, the area would be marked on international navigation charts.

DOC.HEAD: Nigeria Says Military Coup Attempt Crushed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with government saying coup crushed. President's name pronouced: IH-brah-heem bah-bohng-GEE-dah.
DOC.TEXT: The military government said it crushed a coup attempt Sunday after heavy fighting with renegade troops who wanted to break up Nigeria's federation of states to end Moslem domination. The rebellious soldiers battled troops loyal to President Gen. Ibrahim Babangida for control of the capital Sunday after radio reports said that a coup was under way in this sprawling West African nation. But 11 hours after the fighting began, Lt. Gen. Sani Abacha, army chief and chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, went on the radio to say the coup was smashed. He also said Babangida was safe. Abacha's declaration that rebels not already in custody should give themselves up suggested that pockets of resistance remained. The rebellion appeared to be led by middle-ranking officers opposed to traditional domination by Moslem northerners over the central and southern states, which are mainly Christian and animist. Early Sunday, a man identifying himself as Maj. Gideon Ngwozor Oka announced on the Lagos station of Radio Nigeria: ``Fellow Nigerian citizens, on behalf of the patriotic and well-meaning peoples of the Middle Belt and southern parts of this country, I ... wish to happily inform you of the successful ousting of the dictatorial, corrupt, drug-baronish, inhumane, sadistic, deceitful, homosexually centered and unpatriotic administration of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida.'' Oka's announcement accused the northern states of Borno, Bauchi, Kano, Katsina and Sokoto of ``messing up'' the rest of the country through their domination. He said those states would not be allowed to be part of Nigeria until they fulfilled conditions proving loyalty to a new government. Some Radio Nigeria stations in other cities continued broadcasting normally. Moslems are in a slight majority in Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, with 100 million people. A similar conflict caused the 1967-1969 Biafran War. More than 500,000 civilians and 100,000 soldiers died when easterners attempted to form the state of Biafra and secede from Nigeria's federation. Babangida took power in a barracks coup on Aug. 27, 1985. Nigeria, an oil-rich nation, became independent from Britain in 1960.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Kidnappers Set New Time for Hostage Release
DOC.TEXT: Pro-Iranian, Shiite Moslem extremists said Sunday they will free one of three American educators they hold within 24 hours. Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine made the announcement in a hand-written statement delivered to Beirut's independent An-Nahar daily and a Western news agency. The statement did not say which of the Americans the group has held since Jan. 24, 1987, will be freed. But it was authenticated by an instant photograph of one of the three hostages, Robert Polhill.

DOC.HEAD: German Unification Already Occurring Along Vanishing Frontier
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Evelyn Dietrich wrapped a hot sausage at her snack bar in Heiligenstadt's tiny market square, then glanced to see how many customers a visiting West German competitor was getting. ``Sometimes it's hard to believe there's a border anymore,'' she said. Politicians still debate when and how Germany's division will end officially, but practical unification is happening rapidly along the hilly frontier. Heiligenstadt, population 16,000, and other East German border towns are at the heart of the change. West German department stores advertise regularly in the town newspapers, offering everything from pantyhose to chain saws. Social gatherings of East and West Germans are as common as walking across the street for a neighborly visit. West German businessmen anticipating future profits stock the stores with electronic goods and clothing. West German beer is a favorite in the taverns. In Heiligenstadt, Ms. Dietrich's stand is next to a huge sausage van run by an entrepreneur from nearby Eschwege, West Germany. ``Our prices are far better than his, so we don't have any trouble keeping our customers,'' she said. ``In fact, some of our best customers are from the West.'' Over Easter, thousands of Mercedes, BMWs, Volkswagens and other West German cars plied the narrow road that winds through the hills to Heiligenstadt, a spa that retains some of its old charm despite decades of communist neglect and coal-befouled air. East German border officials waved them through, often without even a cursory check. West Germany's currency is not expected to replace the East German mark until summer, as part of an economic union in which West Germans probably will run most of the business, but an unofficial merger is under way. West German business people have swarmed across the border, checking out market prospects and buildings where they can open stores, preparing for the day when doing business in East Germany will be much the same as at home. State-owned East German stores are selling West German goods. Eastern bank accounts are being filled with the East mark profits of West German businessmen who hope for a bonanza when the Deutschemark bcomes East Germany's legal tender. Uwe Fritsch, 30, runs a shop in nearby Muehlhausen that once sold second-hand goods but now stocks electronics goods from West Germany. ``Last week a truck came in loaded with cassette recorders and other products,'' he said. ``Everything was sold out within three days. We had to hand over some of the goods to other shops in Muehlhausen because we didn't have the personnel to deal with it.'' Fritsch said the prices of West German televisions and stereos were lower than those of comparable domestic goods cost, which were rarely available. Coming together also causes problems. West Germans are buying up vast quantities of East German goods at relatively low state-subsidized prices, creating hostility among their poorer cousins. Property ownership is another sore point. Mayor Bernd Beck cited ``many instances'' of West Germans who once lived in Heiligenstadt trying to claim property they left behind. ``There are some who once owned businesses here and want them back,'' he said. Beck said nothing can be done until the two Germanys agree on how to settle the claims, and added: ``We can't throw anybody out on the street. That wouldn't be fair.'' East Germans fear thousands of jobs will be lost as the planned economy is replaced by free-market operations. ``People are very uneasy about what the price of economic union with the West will be,'' said Roswitha Vogler, who works at a meat market in Muellhausen. Economists have said up to 2 million East German jobs could be lost because many factories and businesses will lose out to competitors from the wealthy West. West German products have been something of a mixed blessing for East Germans. Even though electronic goods are generally cheaper and more plentiful, some other Western products cost up to three times what East Germans are used to paying. Employees of a women's store said they still sell only East German clothing because few people in Heiligenstadt could afford items made in the West. When customers have a choice of most goods, however, the domestic product usually loses out. ``From juice to lemonade to yogurt, there's so much from over there,'' Fritsch said. ``Our people crave goods from the Golden West, but leave products made here sitting on the shelves.''

DOC.HEAD: Pontiff to Visit Cuba in December
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II will visit Cuba in December, a Vatican spokesman said Sunday. Spokesman Joaquin Navarro told reporters traveling with the pope in Czechoslovakia that the trip, long in the planning, would take place before Christmas. But the exact date was not set. The Vatican last year accepted an invitation from both the Cuban bishops' conference and Cuban leader Fidel Castro.

DOC.HEAD: Agency Therapy for Alzheimer's Victims Threatened
DOC.TEXT: Judy Kersetter remembers when her mother used to wander in the house, stopping only to pick up newspapers or magazines that she couldn't even read. But that was before Martha Young, 77, began attending an Alzheimer's day-care center last year. The center is run by Intergenerational Services Inc., which may stop operating at the end of the month because of a dispute with an insurance company over whether its services can be considered psychotherapy. ``She's more alert, much more responsive. She seems more aware of what's going on around her. And her communication skills have improved tremendously,'' said Mrs. Kersetter, who has been taking care of her mother for the last five years. Nationwide Insurance, the carrier for Medicare in Ohio, began rejecting claims for the agency's services Oct. 1. The Columbus-based insurance company contends Intergenerational's programs are recreational and social, and do not qualify as psychotherapy under Medicare guidelines. Nationwide and Intergenerational agree that Medicare's guidelines on what constitutes psychotherapy treatment for Alzheimer's are vague. ``Medicare carriers are paid to apply judgment to the claims that are being filed, and we have to use very basic and vague guidelines,'' said Jeannine Keating, Nationwide's manager of administrative support services. ``I think if you ask most people what they consider to be psychotherapy, it's not sitting five people in a circle playing bean bag.'' Intergenerational says Nationwide is trying to drive the agency out of business because of the amount of its claims. Caught in the middle are 2,000 families who depend on Intergenerational programs to help family members with Alzheimer's, a degenerative brain disorder that slowly robs its victims of memory and intellectual functioning. The agency also helps people with other forms of dementia, or severely diminished mental capacity. ``I'm very worried,'' said Mrs. Kersetter, whose mother has been going to the center four days a week. ``If the services stop, she'll regress rapidly. She'll lose the ability to respond. She'll become very passive, vegetative.'' Intergenerational, a non-profit agency founded five years ago in Toledo, offers what the agency considers to be psychotherapy services to victims of Alzheimer's and related dementia in 66 nursing homes in 15 northwest Ohio counties. The agency said it would close by the end of the month unless Nationwide changes its policy. Since October, more than 40,000 claims totaling about $1.1 million have not been paid to Intergenerational. The agency depends on Medicare for 80 percent of its $2.5 million annual budget. Nationwide withheld payments pending a hearing last month by a company examiner. The examiner ruled that the payments were not medically necessary. Intergenerational has appealed the decision. Susan Lemle, Intergenerational's program director, said the services may appear to be simple, but they help patients become more sociable and ease depression. ``We do some singing, do different things to get people to interact with each other,'' Ms. Lemle said. ``For instance, we might have them introduce themselves to each other, shake hands, maybe play games with another person. We might do some kind of word game, or pick a specific topic of the day. All this gives them an opportunity to talk about things they've done in the past. It raises their self-esteem.'' Medicare does not have specific guidelines involving psychotherapy for Alzheimer's patients, said Steven Arney, chief of carrier operations for the federal Health Care Finance Administration, which runs Medicare. But he said Intergenerational's problem is that most of the agency's programs, while they are under the general supervision of doctors, are not conducted by licensed psychotherapists and therefore cannot be fully reimbursed. If the insurance company running the Medicare program in Ohio chooses not to reimburse at all, Arney said, such a decision would be within the federal guidelines. Arney said he knew of no other program in the country serving Alzheimer's patients where a similar dispute over whether to define it as psychotherapy has arisen. Intergenerational, which began at the suggestion of a Toledo nursing home, has trained seven agencies in Ohio to begin similar programs. Ms. Keating said Nationwide will examine the other programs after the Intergenerational case. ``We'll be looking at more than Intergenerational. We'll take appropriate action once the investigation is concluded,'' Ms. Keating said. Meantime, a group known as Advocates for Alzheimer's Victims is circulating petitions asking that Nationwide resume Medicare funding to the agency. It intends to present them to state legislators to pressure Nationwide to reverse its policy. Eleven area chapters of the American Association of Retired Persons are helping. ``We're fighting for our lives,'' Reber said. ``And if we lose, it's the people with Alzheimer's who are going to suffer.''

DOC.HEAD: Gas Leaking From Old Oil Well Forces Town Evacuation
DOC.TEXT: Authorities early today evacuated about 300 people in and around this northeast Texas town after an old oil well began leaking a harmful gas. The leak of hydrogen sulfide was discovered about 5:30 a.m. and was shut down a short time later. But the evacuation was ordered because some gas lingered in the area. Some people complained of nausea and difficulty breathing, but felt better when they left the area. In large doses, the gas can be fatal, authorities said. About 300 people had been moved from their homes by 10 a.m. Many of those have been sent to a school in the community of Liberty-Elyau. Dave Hall, emergency management coordinator at nearby Texarkana, said people may be able to return home by noon after winds dissipate the gas. There have been no injuries, but an ambulance was standing by, officials said. Staff at the Red River Army Depot, a short distance from Redwater, have not been told to evacuate, said Jay Higgs of the Bowie County office of emergency services. Redwater is in the northeast corner of Texas not far from the Arkansas border.

DOC.HEAD: Rowny Urges Soviets To Admit Other Katyn-Like Atrocities
DOC.TEXT: Ambassador Edward L. Rowny urged the Soviet Union on Sunday to follow up on its admission of guilt in the 1940 massacre of thousands of Polish officers in the Katyn Forest and ``tell the whole truth'' about all such acts in its history. Rowny, who is President Bush's special adviser on arms control, said that while Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has made real progress in ``filling in the blank spots'' in Soviet history, ``the conscience of the world demands that it do more.'' ``Genocidal totalitarianism didn't start with Stalin,'' Rowny said in remarks prepared for delivery at a ceremony in Jersey City, N.J., sponsored by Polish-American organizations at the Katyn Forest Memorial. A text of his remarks was released in Washington. ``We must be very clear on this point because communism's apologists would like us to believe that all the blood on Moscow's hands is the fault of the `Stalinist personality cult' and not of communism itself,'' Rowny said. ``For the Soviet authorities to admit to the full scope of communism's crimes will be painful, but it will also be a purifying step,'' he said. ``That is why we continue to challenge the Soviet regime to renounce totalitarianism and all of its works.''

DOC.HEAD: Ceausescus Beg For Mercy, Weep in New Execution Footage
DOC.TEXT: Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu wept silently and his wife Elena begged for mercy as soldiers readied them for the firing squad, according to footage of their execution broadcast Sunday. Extracts of the graphic 90-minute videotape were aired exclusively by the French television network TF1. They are the most detailed look yet at the execution Dec. 25 at a military base outside Bucharest. The Ceausescus were executed days after being toppled by a popular revolution. ``Don't attack us! We have the right to die the way we want,'' Elena Ceausescu told soldiers and the 10-person civilian-military tribunal that sentenced the couple to death. ``Children ...'' Mrs. Ceausescu sniffed at the soldiers who tied her hands behind her back. ``You are bruising my hands. This is shameful. Why, why? I raised you all like a mother.'' Nicolae Ceausescu, who ruled Romania with an iron fist for a quarter-century, struggled briefly with the soldiers but said nothing. Tears rolled down his cheeks. Soldiers placed the couple, who were not blindfolded, against a brick wall and others rapidly opened fire, emptying their magazines. The Ceausescus crumpled under the bullets, which also peppered the brick wall. A medic then looked for signs of life in the eyes of Elena Ceausescu as blood poured from her head. He found none. Subsequent images showed Nicolae Ceausescu embalmed and prepared for burial. His face appeared broken and gray. Gelu Voican, the gray-bearded civilian who organized the proceedings, later was filmed before the two graves where he said the Ceausescus were buried in an Orthodox ceremony. Voican serves as vice prime minister in the interim government headed by Prime Minister Ion Iliescu. Elections to form a new government are scheduled for late May. Previous excerpts made public from the same tape have shown only the Ceausescus at the trial and their lifeless, cleaned bodies laying before the brick wall. The cameraman recording the execution was accidentally wounded, said TF1 journalist Patrick Bourrat.

DOC.HEAD: Gathering to Focus on Housing Problems Worldwide
DOC.TEXT: About half of city dwellers in the Third World are squatters, living in homemade shacks or mud huts on borrowed land with no electricity or plumbing. Even in industrialized nations such as the Soviet Union, extended families live cheek by jowl in aging high-rises, and in the United States a growing number of people can barely afford housing or are homeless despite record levels of home-building during the last 40 years. ``It's safe to say there's hardly a country in the world that has found a solution to adequate housing,'' said Norman Flynn, president of the National Association of Realtors, which is sponsoring a Washington conference on the world housing dilemma this week. Following an opening speech by Housing Secretary Jack Kemp on Tuesday, representatives from 350 public and private organizations from more than 65 countries will examine case studies from 13 nations describing their housing experiences and ideas for improvements. The meeting will focus on increasing the private sector's involvement in low-income housing. One of the major problems in developing countries is the mass migration of rural residents to cities in search of better lives, said Michael Cohen, director of the World Bank's Urban Division. In 1950, there were 273 million people living in urban areas of less developed countries, Cohen said. By 1975, that number had swelled to 819 million, and the projection for the year 2000 is 2.1 billion. ``Mega-cities'' such as Mexico City now hold 25 million people, and Sao Paolo, Brazil, has attracted 20 million, said Cohen. A vast number of these migrants have been forced to take up residence as squatters at city fringes, living in unsafe, homemade structures illegally built on someone else's land, he said. ``In Latin America it's frequently shacks. In Africa, it's frequently mud huts,'' said Cohen. ``In the 1980s, probably half the population in most major Third World cities lived in squatter areas or slums,'' which usually lack electricity, toilet facilities and water. The World Bank, which draws its funds from national government and world capital markets, lent 60 developing countries $10.1 billion for housing and urban development projects between 1972 and June 1990, Cohen said. But the bank increasingly is funneling money through governments to private enterprise, he said. In the Soviet Union, where people pay nominal rent to live in cramped quarters in ``monotonous'' government-owned apartment buildings, attempts are being made to improve quality of life and create more individual investment, says Alexander Krivov, who coordinated a Soviet case study. New programs aim to nearly double home building by encouraging more private construction and ownership, concentrating efforts on single-family homes in the suburbs, said Krivov, who is vice chairman of the State Committee on Architecture and Urban Planning in Moscow. ``Single-family houses with pieces of land around it _ it's another pattern of life, another quality of life,'' he said. In the United States, where nearly all housing is built by private developers, the gap between the ``haves and the have-nots'' is increasing, said John Tuccillo, coordinator of the U.S. case study and senior vice president and chief economist for the Realtors association. Tuccillo said building regulations designed to protect the public's welfare have become a burden instead, increasing developers' costs, limiting flexibility and wasting time. ``It's a case for easing those standards a bit to allow the production of housing that's within the reach of folks who have a hard time acquiring housing,'' he said. Other countries presenting case studies at the conference include Zimbabwe, India, Indonesia, Thailand, China, Trinidad and Tobago, Chile, Bolivia, Colombia, Portugal and West Germany. The meeting is the third public-private convention held to discuss housing needs worldwide. China, the Soviet Union and Eastern bloc countries will participate for the first time.

DOC.HEAD: Rural AIDS Epidemic Spawning Same Fears as Early Stages of Urban Crisis
DOC.TEXT: It was like a journey back in time when the National AIDS Commission traveled to south Georgia last week for a firsthand look at how rural areas are coping with the deadly disease. ``I'm afraid we're seeing history repeat itself,'' said Dr. June Osborn, chairwoman of the panel, after the commission spent two days in Waycross, Albany and Macon visiting with AIDS patients and talking with health care professionals. ``The same fear, the same isolation for people with AIDS, the same difficulty in mobilizing coordinated care that we saw in the beginning of the urban epidemic back a few years ago is happening all over again,'' she said. The commission's trip came on the heels of a federal Centers for Disease Control report that AIDS is spreading more rapidly in rural areas than in cities. From 1988 to 1989, the CDC found that nonmetropolitan areas had a 37 percent increase in new AIDS cases while metro areas had only a 5 percent gain. In Georgia, the state Department of Human Resources reported in January that the number of AIDS cases had tripled in two years, with the rapid spread of the disease in rural parts of the state linked to drug users and heterosexual transmission. Rep. Roy Rowland, D-Ga., a member of the commission, agreed with Osborn's assessment that history may be repeating itself. But Rowland, a physician who practiced in rural Dublin, Ga., for 28 years before being elected to Congress, said he does not think rural areas will have as much difficulty overcoming those problems of fear and discrimination as urban areas have had. ``There's a lot more acceptance of the fact that this is a disease that we need to be fighting and not fighting the people who have the disease,'' Rowland said. ``I don't think the battle is going to be as tough in rural areas because of that.'' Still, Osborn said she was shocked at the extent to which health care professionals in rural Georgia were avoiding AIDS cases. ``Some of the public fear is bouncing off the fear of health professionals,'' she said. ``It was striking to us that while there were some very committed people doing wonderful work, there was also an undercurrent of health professionals not really wanting to touch these people.'' In south Georgia as in most rural areas, commission members said they found a health care system even less prepared to deal with an onslaught of AIDS cases than the already overburdened health care systems in cities like New York and San Francisco. ``The rural health care system is much more fragile than the urban, just on a matter of scale and the fact that many of these rural areas already have severe doctor shortages,'' Osborn said. Since even a small number of AIDS cases could overburden a struggling rural hospital, Osborn said it is critical that people infected with the HIV virus in rural areas be treated in the early stages of the disease and continuously thereafter. ``In the big cities where AIDS is already hitting as hard as it is, it's going to be very hard to play catchup because you've already got hospitals teetering,'' she said. ``But in rural areas, if one were paying good attention and shoring up some of the existing primary health care and public health capabilities, it's possible you could get out in front before the number of cases gets overwhelming,'' she said. Both Osborn and Rowland said they expect the commission to take an active role in urging Congress to provide new funding to attack the AIDS problem in rural areas. The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee earlier this month unanimously approved a bill that would provide $600 million in emergency funds to help alleviate the AIDS care crisis. Half of the $600 million would be directed to cities with more than 2,000 AIDS cases, but the other half would go to states to permit them to develop comprehensive HIV care programs in small cities and rural areas. AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, is a contagious disease that attacks the body's immune system, rendering it incapable of resisting other diseases and infections. The disease is spread most often through sexual contact, needles or syringes shared by drug abusers, infected blood or blood products, and from infected pregnant women to their offspring.

DOC.HEAD: In Campaign Fund Raising, Advantage: Incumbent
DOC.TEXT: A month after announcing her Senate candidacy, New Jersey Republican Christine Todd Whitman had raised $70,000, or roughly $2,300 a day. Not bad for a little-known challenger. But Whitman's opponent, Democratic Sen. Bill Bradley, has been raising $5,000 a day for more than five years. That's more than $9 million. Whitman's situation, although extreme, is far from unique. The lifeblood of politics is money, and for challengers cash often is hard to come by. The problem is greatest for challengers like Whitman who never have held major elected office. But the pinch also is being felt by four GOP House members challenging Democratic senators this year; all four trail in the fund-raising race, according to the latest campaign finance reports. Critics of the campaign finance system see the fund-raising imbalance as the main reason so few incumbents are defeated; 98.3 percent of House incumbents were re-elected in 1988. Fred Wertheimer, president of the citizens lobby Common Cause, said the current campaign finance situation is ``a system where incumbents are drowning in special interest money while challengers are starving for resources. It also leads to a challenger-proof Congress.'' Cash-poor challengers with personal wealth frequently resort to lending themselves money, and often end their campaigns with considerable debts. FEC data show Senate challengers relied on personal loans for 10 percent of their campaign money in 1988 elections; House challengers for 19 percent. In Massachusetts, Democratic Sen. John Kerry raised nearly $760,000 in the first three months of 1990, more than double the $470,000 raised by two Republicans vying for the chance to challenge him in November. The GOP totals include a combined $320,000 the challengers lent their campaigns during the first quarter, according to Federal Election Commission reports. House races typically cost less than Senate campaigns, so the fund-raising gap between incumbents and challengers generally is smaller. But there are gaps nonetheless. In Pennsylvania, Democratic Rep. Peter Kostmayer collected $82,000 in donations during the first three months of 1990, according to his quarterly FEC report. His Republican opponent, political newcomer Audrey Zettick Schaller, raised $13,500. Kostmayer, who spent $1 million to win re-election two years ago and has endorsed legislation to limit campaign spending, has refused her request that he agree to a $400,000 spending limit. ``No matter what limits we could come to, he has the advantages of incumbency,'' Schaller said. ``I don't see what his problem is except that he's not good for his word.'' A big factor in the lopsided fund-raising situation is political action committees associated with special interest groups, which offer a seemingly endless source of contributions for incumbents. FEC data show that at this point in 1988 Senate elections, political action committees had contributed nearly $15 million to incumbents and $2.3 million to challengers. In House races, PAC contributions favored incumbents over challengers $32 million to $1.2 million. The four House members giving up seemingly safe seats to take on incumbent senators are getting a taste of the financial challenge to challenging this year. In Illinois, Republican Rep. Lynn Martin raised $482,000 in the first quarter of the year, compared with $556,000 for Democratic Sen. Paul Simon. But Simon's well-stocked warchest left him with $1.5 million on hand compared with $410,000 for Martin as of March 31, according to their FEC filings. Rep. Tom Tauke, R-Iowa, raised $586,000 from January through March and had the best first quarter of the four House members. But his fund-raising still was eclipsed by the $700,000 raised by Sen. Tom Harkin, who ended the quarter with $1.1 million cash on hand compared with Tauke's $293,000. These challengers, however, are in line for considerable party support as the GOP seeks to chip away at the Democratic Senate majority. In the three races for open Senate seats, it is the incumbent House members who have the clear fund-raising edge. In Colorado, Republican Rep. Hank Brown raised $377,000 for his Senate campaign and had $1.1 million on hand at the end of the first quarter. His likely Democratic challenger, Boulder County Commissioner Jodie Heath, raised $126,000 and ended the quarter with $71,000 in the bank. The importance _ and difficulty _ of fund raising is not lost on Heath, who offered this simple assessment during a trip to Washington seeking political action committee support: ``You're just sort of shamelessly begging. That's what federal politics is about.''

DOC.HEAD: Florio's Hands On Style Make First 100 Days Eventful, Dizzying
With AM-Wilder-100 Days, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jim Florio steamrolled opponent James Courter in the race for governor last year with a campaign that was praised as effective but criticized as nasty. As he nears his 100th day as New Jersey's 49th governor on Wednesday, the Florio story line hasn't changed. Supporters praise the Democrat for taking hold of state government with the bold hands-on style of a true leader. Opponents rip Florio for grasping state government with too tight a grip, saying his administration is akin to a monarchy that does not tolerate debate. Clearly, the combative former congressman from Camden did not opt to ease into the job in his first 100 days. With a swiftness that matched the pace of his campaign, Florio, 52, has placed his imprint on virtually every state government operation. ``Jim Florio has demonstrated something that's not all that common in American politics: courage,'' said Ross Baker, political scientist at Rutgers University. ``But frankly, that usually comes from people who are not all that likeable. He's pushing an already powerful office to its limits in a way (predecessors) Tom Kean and Brendan Byrne never did.'' Since January, Florio has pushed through controversial auto insurance reform, postponed a toll increase on the New Jersey Turnpike and proposed $1.4 billion in new taxes, including a sales tax increase from 6 percent to 7 percent, and spending cuts to solve a budget crisis. Florio enraged gun activists by proposing to ban assault weapons, blasted the oil industry for spills in state waterways and traded harsh words with industry officials over his auto insurance reform. Florio has not been shy about blaming former Gov. Thomas H. Kean for New Jersey's budget woes, claiming he was forced to break a campaign promise against raising major taxes because he never knew things were this bad. If he wants a program, Florio battles for it, taking no prisoners in the sometimes dizzying process. ``Everyone seems to think (we've) discovered some new approach for government by facing up to problems and not doing things that are in the short term politically beneficial,'' Florio said in an interview with The Associated Press. ``It may be new for people in Trenton, but it's been my style for a long time.'' When Allstate Insurance Co. officials blasted the plan prior to its first legislative hearing, Florio, a former boxer, came out smoking. ``They say they're the good hands people,'' Florio said at the time. ``The question is, what part of our anatomy do they have their hands around.'' The auto insurance reform moved through the Democratic-controlled legislative process within 45 days, a lightning quick pace by Trenton standards. The 80-page measure faces a court challenge because it forces insurers to pay off half of the $3.1 billion debt facing the state pool for high-risk drivers, which at one point covered more than half of the state's motorists. Auto insurance rates in New Jersey are among the highest in the nation. His budget proposes to increase the sales tax, raise taxes on liquor, cigarettes and oil products, and eliminate a popular homeowner rebate program. The budget includes deep cuts to many programs. GOP leaders oppose the tax increases and claim Florio's strategy is to stockpile state income sources so he can spend more on programs in his re-election year. Florio makes no apologies for the swift movement of his initiatives. ``This reflects the values of the people of the state,'' he said. ``They want problems solved, not later, but sooner. They want things managed in sensible ways.'' ``I'm doing what has to be done to ensure we'll have financial stability in the state and to allow the state's economy to grow,'' he said. ``To not do it will precipitate a financial crisis.'' Baker said Florio will have to be careful about approaching every issue in an aggressive manner. He said lawmakers are slighted by such as manner. ``He needs to stroke people,'' Baker said. ``Legislators are very bad at pursuing their own agenda but they can be very good at wrecking someone else's.'' The governor said he recognizes the risks. ``It's called accountability,'' Florio said. ``I will take the responsibility for things that I initiate and support. If I'm going to be held accountable, that's fine, but give me the authority to deal with it.''

DOC.HEAD: Medfly Adviser Warns Infestation Poses `Major Crisis'
DOC.TEXT: Night after night of aerial pesticide spraying hasn't halted the 50-mile spread of the destructive Medfly from suburban back yards to orange and grapefruit groves in some of the region's richest farmland. New outbreaks this month and the approach of summer weather have some scientists and growers in the nation's No. 1 agricultural state fearing the worst _ costly farm quarantines, or even more serious, foreign embargoes of California produce. Compounding the worries are continual protests against nightly helicopter missions that rain on neighborhoods a malathion-laced syrup that is a primary weapon in the Medfly war. New doubts also have arisen about government insistence that the eradication campaign is working. The newest focus of concern is 10 fresh outbreaks of the Medfly plague this month, all but two of them outside previously treated infestations. ``This is nothing short of a major crisis,'' said entomologist James R. Carey, a member of the state's fruit fly scientific advisory panel. Carey and Richard Rice, a colleague at the University of California, Davis, believe the Medfly has become established throughout California, and that state policy requires an immediate overhaul. ``I can think of no other explanation of what's happening,'' said Carey. He believes the sporadic late-winter Medfly discoveries portend an explosion in Medfly populations by midsummer, when warm weather increases the insect's breeding rates. ``If your house is on fire, and the fire starts in the kitchen, you don't wait until it gets to the bedroom before you call the fire department,'' Rice said. ``We're in deep trouble right now.'' The Mediterranean fruit fly is considered one of the most serious agricultural pests in the world. The insect, smaller than a house fly, lays its eggs in more than 250 varieties of fruits, vegetables and nuts. Within several days, the larvae hatch and feed on the fruit, turning it into an inedible, unsaleable mush. The 1981-82 outbreak in the state and resulting quarantines cost growers $100 million, while another $100 million was spent on eradication. In a March 26 memo circulated among top agriculture officials, Carey argues that a new, long-range and aggressive strategy must be adopted to get rid of the Medfly this time around. ``I feel that a program designed to eradicate the Medfly must be viewed as similar to those designed to eradicate major diseases such as smallpox or malaria,'' Carey wrote. Carey recommends a new research effort to develop better tools to detect and exterminate the Medfly. Nevertheless, officials at the California Department of Food and Agriculture maintain that the $36.5 million Medfly eradication program is working. ``Dr. Carey has not produced any scientific data to prove his hypothesis,'' said Isi Siddiqui, an assistant director of the department. And as a state official who supervises the war against the Medfly, Siddiqui said he must have proof before ordering a new strategy. ``Obviously we are experiencing more difficulties than we expected,'' Siddiqui acknowledged. But he said the treatment program, which mostly uses aerial pesticide spraying and the release of millions of sterile Medflies, will eventually wipe out the crop-destroying pest. Gov. George Deukmejian added his support Thursday, saying, ``The Department of Agriculture is pursuing what is a time-tested method of eradicating the Medfly.'' Other scientists on the state's five-member advisory panel also have failed to be persuaded by Carey and Rice, said chairman Roy Cunningham. ``These finds are of course discouraging, but they aren't really supportive of Carey's thesis,'' Cunningham said. Still, Cunningham acknowledged that he doesn't entirely understand what's happening. Everyone agrees that a fundamental problem in determining the extent of the infestation is the uncertainty of methods used to detect fruit flies. A variety of Medfly traps, some baited with sex lures and others with food, are set out throughout Southern California. But some studies suggest most Medflies ignore the traps. And for each Medfly caught in a trap, scientists estimate, 500 to 1,000 other Medflies are still loose in the vicinity. ``If you ask my wish list, I think I'd like to see a more effective lure that attracts the flies,'' Siddiqui said. The scientific debate, however, has left farmers wondering whom to believe, and fearing what more outbreaks may lead to. ``Sure you dread it,'' said Mike Stuart, a spokesman for the Irvine-based Western Growers Association. ``If your orchard or your packing house or your farm is unlucky enough to be inside a quarantine area on the basis of a fly find ... it's a nightmare.'' The new Medfly discoveries prompted agriculture officials to order aerial spraying in several new areas, including 19 square miles in the Riverside County community of Woodcrest, about 55 miles east of Los Angeles. Agriculture officials also plan to establish a quarantine for 84 square miles around the pesticide treatment zone, including some 3,000 of Riverside County's 37,000 acres of citrus groves.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Takes Revenge on One-Time Ally in Democratic Primary
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Gov. Wallace Wilkinson is playing favorites in his party's U.S. Senate primary this year, training his fire on a onetime ally he claims reneged on a promise. Wilkinson is siding with underdog John Brock, the elected state school superintendent, over Harvey Sloane, whose own campaign for governor in 1983 Wilkinson had championed. Meanwhile, the Republican incumbent, Sen. Mitch McConnell, sits comfortably atop a $3 million campaign fund awaiting a Democratic opponent. Sloane, a physician, former Louisville mayor and Jefferson County judge-executive, says he will win the primary despite the governor's opposition. Wilkinson, who was finance chairman in Sloane's 1983 campaign, claims Sloane reneged on a promise to support him in 1987. Sloane maintains that Wilkinson has put together a network of party contacts to work against him. Polls, however, show little public support being transferred to Brock. ``I just have not seen a dynamic in his campaign,'' Sloane said of Brock. ``I would imagine he's looking toward the latter part of it when the governor can get out for him.'' McConnell, who is seeking a second term and faces only token opposition in the May 29 primary, reserves his attacks for Sloane. ``I don't see much life out of the Brock campaign, and I am assuming Sloane is going to be the opponent,'' he said. But Brock, who entered the race in October banking on Wilkinson's endorsement, is equally confident of victory in the primary. ``I'm always ... running scared and working hard, but I think we're going to win in May without any difficulty,'' Brock said. He takes heart from Sloane's record as a two-time loser in statewide races _ the 1979 and 1983 gubernatorial primaries. ``He got 30 percent of the vote in each of those elections, which means 70 percent of the people voted for another candidate,'' Brock said. Sloane has spent two years preparing to run against McConnell. As of March 31, he had $670,000 in his campaign fund, compared to Brock's $47,000. Although he has the support of the state's teacher organization, trial lawyers and organized labor, Sloane has failed to unite the Democratic hierarchy behind him. Former Gov. Edward ``Ned'' Breathitt endorsed Brock, as did Dr. Grady Stumbo, who ran for governor in 1983 and 1987 and enjoyed wide support in the rural areas of eastern and western Kentucky. Sloane's recent problems include the prospect of employee layoffs and the closing of health clinics in Jefferson County because of a budget crisis left from his term. He also has been hurt by the disclosure that the state Board of Medical Licensure had privately criticized him for prescribing his own sleeping pills, even though he maintains no active medical practice. That Brock has not tried to exploit those issues puzzles some observers, including McConnell. ``Frankly, if Brock were better at running for office, he could win the primary based upon what's out there already,'' McConnell said. Sloane's most conspicuous problem, however, has been Wilkinson's enmity. The governor has consistently bashed Sloane as too liberal for Kentucky voters _ a theme echoed by Brock. It is, in fact, about the only direct criticism the soft-spoken Brock is willing to make. Sloane ``is a fine man and I like him very much, but I don't think his philosophy is what most Kentuckians want in Washington,'' Brock said. ``I'm running for the United States Senate. I'm not running against Harvey Sloane.''

DOC.HEAD: Census Workers Prepare to Hit the Bricks
DOC.TEXT: The Census Bureau, under attack for missing millions of people when it mailed out forms to Americans, is now dispatching an army of people to count heads. An estimated 330,000 enumerators will be making the rounds of America's houses, apartments and condominiums to count those who didn't return their census forms. ``We will visit each housing unit that did not return a questionnaire ... and we have the workforce to do it,'' said Census Bureau Director Barbara Everitt Bryant. The workforce is larger than anticipated because of a poorer than expected return of the mass mailing from the government last month. Training of the workers who will go America's homes and apartments begins Monday with the actual counting scheduled to start Thursday. The cost of the door-to-door canvas is expected to add $150 million or more to the price of the census, originally estimated at $1.3 billion for this year. Results of the census will be used to determine congressional representation for the next decade and the distribution of federal aid for programs ranging from help for the homeless to funds for the war on drugs. Problems in the initial mailing have caused a chorus of complaints that the census is being mishandled. Some Americans simply didn't return their forms. Others _ including one entire town in California _ never received them in the first place. ``It's early in the census process and there is much to be done,'' said Rep. Thomas Sawyer. D-Ohio, chairman of the House subcommittee supervising the census. Rep. Mervyn Dymally, D-Calif., says the project is on the brink of disaster and Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., has called for a Senate investigation. The Census Bureau had hoped that 70 percent of Americans would send back their forms. As of Friday, the rate was only 63 percent, forcing the bureau to hire more people to continue the count. Bryant said that the Bureau has a pool of 1.4 million qualified job applicants nationwide. That provides more than four people for each of the 330,000 jobs to be filled, she said. Unfortunately, she said, the applicants are not evenly distributed. There is double the national average available for each job in New York, for example, but a slight shortage of available workers on Long Island. A study by the General Accounting Office concluded that nearly half the bureau's local offices had fewer than four applicants for every job. And the GAO found that pre-census work was slowed by staff shortages in 15 of the 109 district offices open in 1989. In the pre-canvass work developing address lists, for example, some workers from the Philadelphia area were sent to help in Newark, N.J. The same occurred in the New York City and Los Angeles areas. To help fill scattered shortages of census workers, Congress has permitted retired federal workers and military personnel to take temporary census jobs without losing their retirement benefits. In addition, the Department of Housing and Urban Affairs is permitting residents of subsidized housing to accept census jobs without the extra income causing their rent to go up. Similar rulings now apply to recipients of food stamps and other public assistance. Hiring census takers is a particular problem in areas with low unemployment. Where necessary, the bureau will hire people from neighboring communities to conduct the count. But, for a variety of reasons, it prefers relying on local residents. First, they are more comfortable walking the halls of large apartment buildings and along ghetto streets. In addition, they are more likely to be familiar with local languages and geography and trusted more by local residents wary of outsiders. Using local residents a census takers is considered especially important in Hispanic areas, where people are afraid that giving any information to the government will lead to a visit by immigration officials. The Census Bureau has worked hard to stress the confidentiality of the answers people give and many Hispanic groups have worked to encourage public cooperation.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Paul McCartney sang old Beatles hits for 130,000 fans jammed into Rio's Maracana soccer stadium Saturday to end a scheduled 33-city tour.
