DOC.HEAD: Text of Tehran Times Editorial on Hostages
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of the editorial in Monday's edition of the English-language Tehran Times daily on the hostage issue. The Iranian newspaper often reflects the views of Iran's president, Hashemi Rafsanjani.

The release of the first Western hostage in Beirut is now a reality. This necessitates that those involved should now even enhance their well-intentioned common moves and cooperation and expedite their efforts to ensure the continuation of the release process for all the hostages. Undoubtedly and for a fact the settlement of the hostage issue in Lebanon and occupied Palestine is beyond any single country. It requires an all-out effort on the part of all the concerned parties. The Islamic republic, in using its spiritual clout along this line, virtually left no stone unturned. The Iranians' painstaking and continuous efforts in this connection over the recent months have actually proven that the whole thing is a highly complicated matter. One just cannot hope to achieve anything without paying due attention to the rightful demands of the Lebanese groups involved. The Tehran Times believes that to contribute to the establishment of a general atmosphere of trust, the Lebanese groups should release another American hostage. By doing so, they once more prove their goodwill and preparedness for the settlement of the issue. The Lebanese groups will certainly find it hard to comply with this request and their position is quite understandable. But perhaps the release of one hostage alone will not be enough to establish the kind of overwhelming trust needed to bring the whole hostage crisis to an end. But for both the Lebanese groups and the Islamic republic officials, it is Islamic and humane considerations that count most. Goodwill should not come from one side only. It is a two-way street. The Tehran Times, however, from the very beginning has believed in the unconditional freedom of all hostages on Islamic and humanitarian grounds only. This daily believes that the release process must be expedited by acts of goodwill by the concerned party on the other side. To negotiate with Lebanese groups, which have been subject to all kinds of hardship under Israeli aggression and while scores of their brothers are held in captivity in Lebanon and occupied Palestine is certainly not an easy task. Their trampled rights should never be eclipsed by anything. Even the Islamic republic will not succeed in its efforts to get the hostages released if it fails to consider the rightful demands of these oppressed groups. But if the other party too displays its goodwill, Iranian efforts can be facilitated to ensure the release of all hostages in 1990. We do believe that the Lebanese groups should still free a second American hostage with no pre-conditions. This they should do swiftly in order to leave the ball in the other party's court to demonstrate its goodwill, if it has any. In fact, the Iranian people and government have no faith in the U.S. administration. But perhaps it is now time to test President Bush's claims that ``goodwill begets goodwill.''

DOC.HEAD: Marrow Brings Mahalia Jackson to Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: The strength of ``Truly Blessed'' is its tone _ of sincerity, simplicity and dignity _ plus the joyful noise of its music. ``Truly Blessed,'' which opened at Broadway's Longacre Theater on Sunday afternoon, is the story of the great gospel singer Mahalia Jackson performed by Queen Esther Marrow, also a respected gospel singer. Miss Marrow had the idea for ``Truly Blessed'' and wrote some of the songs that compellingly tell the story. There also are traditional spirituals: ``St. Louis Blues,'' which Miss Jackson _ known as ``Haley'' _ listened to as a girl, and ``He's Got the Whole World in His Hand,'' a song identified with Miss Jackson in her last years. Four singers provide a chorus. All of them can be occasionally shrill but Miss Marrow never is. Her voice, in a lower register like Miss Jackson's, is a straightforward power and doesn't need excitement-seeking high flourishes. One difference: Miss Jackson bent her notes in a bluesy way more than Miss Marrow does. Miss Marrow obviously decided not to imitate. A combo of musicians is at one side of the stage. A platform with two sets of steps fills the rest of the space, backed by what looks like big organ pipes. Miss Marrow wears a succession of choir robes, housedress, blue wedding dress, suits and gowns. She talks between songs. Mahalia Jackson wouldn't sing in nightclubs. Early in ``Truly Blessed,'' Miss Marrow, always in character, says that she could have sung the blues but she liked singing gospel because they were songs of hope, that God could cure what was wrong. ``You get done with the blues, you got nothing to rest on.'' Miss Jackson joined the Greater Salem Baptist Church choir after she moved to Chicago with an aunt. She and the quartet push chairs together to depict ``the lean years'' _ car travel with the Johnson Gospel Singers, one of the first professional touring gospel groups. They discuss a preacher who thought Miss Jackson's ``joyful noise'' was too jazzy and the discomforts of not being able to stop the car in the South. Brief scenes show Miss Jackson singing at a Mayor Richard Daley rally in Chicago, marrying Sigmond Galloway and everybody dancing at a restaurant afterwards, praying before singing at Carnegie Hall, marching with Martin Luther King, and readying to sing in Europe and visit the Holy Land. A longer scene in which Miss Jackson is asked dumb, esoteric questions at a convention of musicologists is contrived but funny. Robert Kalfin directs. Producers are Howard Hurst, Philip Rose and Sophie Hurst in association with Frankie Hewitt. ``Truly Blessed'' was first produced at Ford's Theater in Washington. House lights go on twice, to show people clapping along. But the show isn't a rave-up. It's lively but respectful of the artist who first impressed many in the world of the value of gospel music.

DOC.HEAD: Condor Missile Project Halted
DOC.TEXT: The defense minister said Argentina has halted development of a medium-range missile that arms control experts said could carry a chemical or nuclear warhead, newspapers reported Sunday. ``The Condor 2 project is paralyzed. It is not going ahead because of a political decision and the lack of funds,'' the defense minister, Humberto Romero, said in remarks reported in several newspapers Sunday. ``The project is frozen.'' Development of the missile began in the 1980s and diplomatic sources have said Iraq provided financing and Egypt lent techological expertise. The Condor 2 missile, which Argentina has stressed would only be used to launch satellites, is reportedly powerful enough to carry a 3,300-pound warhead 625 miles. Arms experts have repeatedly stated that the missile could carry a nuclear or chemical warhead. In his remarks Romero said the development of the missile ``in no way signified a risk or danger to anyone.'' In September, President Carlos Menem reportedly told President Bush that Argentina was considering ending the Condor project. In May, Assistant Secretary of State Allen Holmes told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee that the development of the Condor 2 was years behind schedule ``and we believe this can be traced to problems in acquiring technology.'' He said nations that are signatories to the Missile Technology Control Regime had been denying Argentina the technology necessary for the rocket's development. The missile treaty was established to limit the spread of rockets to the Third World and has been signed by nations including the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada. Egypt apparently dropped out of the Condor project several months ago, partially due to pressure from the United States. Iraq's missile program has been rapidly advancing. In December, Iraq's Minister of Industry and Military Industrialization, Hussein Kamel, announced that Baghdad had launched a three-stage rocket capable of launching satellites. Iraqi officials also claimed Iraq had test-fired two surface-to-surface missiles with ranges of 1,240 miles.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Block Downtown Bucharest
DOC.TEXT: About 600 protesters demanding the resignation of interim President Ion Iliescu blocked University Square on Sunday, capping a day of demonstrations in Romania that attracted tens of thousands. The protesters barricaded themselves behind wooden advertising panels in front of the Intercontinental Hotel and chanted: ``Down with Communism! This government is definitely Communist!'' Several hundred police, including 120 riot troops equipped with nightsticks and plastic shields, ringed the demonstrators but did not intervene. The protesters, demonstrating in front of the Intercontinental Hotel, were part of a rally of 5,000 that earlier Sunday marched to Romanian television requesting that it become independent from government control. The frequency of rallies has increased recently as elections draw near. The May 20 balloting will be Romania's first free elections in more than 50 years. At least 70 political parties are entered. The University Square protesters wrote slogans in white chalk on the pavement: ``Down with FSN!'' and ``FSN has confiscated the revolution!'' FSN is the National Salvation Front, the party that took power immediately after the December revolution that ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were found guilty of ``grave crimes'' and executed Dec. 25. The Front, whose leading members are former Communists who declared they broke from the party after the revolution, is accused by the opposition parties of promoting a milder version of Marxism. ``Our unity here is a guarantee to save Romania from the biggest danger, which is represented by the Front,'' said Nicolae Popescu, a student who belongs to the Partyless Movement, the organizer of the rally. Iliescu, 60, a former Communist Party secretary, ran afoul of Ceausescu and was demoted to lesser jobs. He is the Front's candidate for president. The Front, which claims some 800,000 members, is widely seen as the most organized of the parties, drawing support mainly from industrial workers and former Communist Party members.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Republican Candidate Admits Visiting Prostitutes As Young Man
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4 grafs for 6th graf pvs, `Williams was...,' to UPDATE with statement from his press secretary. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `Last month...
DOC.TEXT: The admission by gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams that he patronized prostitutes as a young man raises new questions about his attitudes toward women, his opponent's campaign said Sunday. ``In recent months, the Republican nominee has made several comments which, taken together, drive this wedge between men and women, and I think that's unfortunate,'' said Glenn Smith, manager of state Treasurer Ann Richards' campaign for governor. Smith said Ms. Richards, the Democratic candidate, was vacationing and would not comment on Williams' admissions, which appeared Sunday in The Houston Post. ``I've never claimed to be a perfect man,'' Williams told the newspaper in discussing his use of prostitutes. ``It's part of growing up in West Texas. ... ``It's like the Larry McMurtry book, `The Last Picture Show,''' said the Fort Stockton native, a 58-year-old political neophyte who won the GOP nomination last month after spending millions of dollars of his own money. Williams was in Arizona on Sunday and unavailable to answer questions. His press secretary, Bill Kenyon, released the following statement: ``One of Clayton's greatest strengths as a person is one of his greatest `weaknesses' as a politician; he always tries to be honest. ... ``When Clayton was tracked down by a reporter chasing outlandish rumors about Clayton's past that have been fanned by the Richards campaign and other Democrats, he dismissed them as absurd. ``Most politicians would have stopped there,'' the statement continued. ``But when the reporter went further and asked if he had ever visited a prostitute, Clayton surprised some folks by conceding once again that he's not perfect and by telling the truth about incidents earlier in his life, even when it wasn't politically expedient.'' Last month, Williams stirred criticism from women's groups by making a joking about rape. He later apologized. Williams, interviewed during an independent oil group meeting in Scottsdale, Ariz., told the Post he paid prostitutes a number of times in Texas and Mexico. He said it had been at least 35 years since he did so. ``As a teen-ager, it's part of growing up in West Texas. You go to Mexico. It's part of the fun,'' he said. Williams added that he patronized prostitutes while a student at Texas A&M University, adding that ``it was kind of what the boys did at A&M,'' he said. ``It was a lot different in those days. The houses were the only place you got serviced then.'' Prostitution is illegal in Texas and was illegal 35 years ago; it is legal in parts of Mexico. In a telephone interview from Houston, Smith said Williams' ``private behavior is best left to him and his family'' and not a legitimate subject for a campaign. But he also said Williams' comments about women should be a topic of debate. ``He implies that women are here to `service' men. That kind of an attitude is as insulting to men as it is to women,'' Smith said. Ms. Richards won the Democratic nomination on April 10 after a mudslinging runoff campaign in which her opponent, Attorney General Jim Mattox, accused her of using illegal drugs as recently as 10 years ago but offered no evidence. Ms. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, declined to answer questions about illegal drug use, saying her addiction had been alcohol and that public discussions might discourage others from seeking treatment. During a cattle roundup on his ranch last month, Williams likened bad weather to rape and said that if it was inevitable, ``just relax and enjoy it.'' The next day, he said he was sorry and said he realized his comment was insensitive. However, during a visit to Washington before the Democratic runoff, Williams told reporters he would feel uncomfortable running against a woman. The millionaire businessman-rancher won the GOP nomination with 61 percent of the vote in a seven-man race March 13 after spending more than $8 million on the race, including $6 million of his own funds. In his interview with the Post, Williams said the final decision belongs to voters but that he doesn't believe that a candidate's private life as a youth should have any bearing on his ability to lead. ``If doing drugs 10 years ago is all right, then certainly I think going to a Mexican border town 40 years ago is all right,'' Williams said, alluding to allegations against Ms. Richards.

DOC.HEAD: Denktash Wins Fourth Term As Head of Turkish Cypriot State
DOC.TEXT: Turkish-dominated northern Cyprus overwhelmingly re-elected Rauf Denktash to a fourth term as president Sunday. With 80 percent of the ballots counted, Denktash had 52,915 votes or 67 percent, the election board announced. Denktash, 66, ran on an independent ticket for a five-year term. His chief rival, Ismail Bozkurt, also an independent, captured 31.7 percent. Alpay Durduran of the New Cyprus Party had 1.3 percent. No violence was reported. Polls were open between 8 a.m. and 6 p.m. Complete returns were expected Monday. Claiming victory, Denktash called on Greek Cypriots to accept the Turkish Cypriots' right to self-determination. ``We invite them to friendship,'' he said. Cyrpus, whose population is 78 percent Greek and 19 percent Turkish, achieved independence from Britain in 1960. Internal strife between Turks and Greeks led to an invasion by Turkey in July 1974, after Athens-led coup seized the government. A cease-fire collapsed and by August 1974, Turkish forces occupied 40 percent of the island in the north. Turkish Cypriots voted in 1975 to form a separate state and declared full independence in November 1983, changing the name to Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus from the previous Turkish federated state of Cyprus. Denktash was elected president of the Turkish federated state in 1976, 1981 and 1985. Turkey is the only country which recognizes the breakaway state. Sunday's election came two weeks before legislative elections. That ballotting may determine the outcome of stalled peace talks aimed at reuniting the island.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Official Warns Lithuania of Catastrophe Ahead
LaserPhoto VIL1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14 grafs for grafs 4-19 pvs, `The streets...' to UPDATE with Soviet legislator condemning economic sanctions. MOVES UP comments by Communist official. Pickup pvs 20th graf, ``The Sajudis...' ^MARK J. PORUBCANSKY
DOC.TEXT: A senior Communist official from Moscow said Sunday the Lithuanian independence movement is leading the republic to catastrophe, and denied the Kremlin has imposed a total economic blockade. The Sajudis independence movement, whose leaders dominate Lithuania's government, declared its determination to stand by the March 11 declaration of independence. In neighboring Latvia, meanwhile, the drive for independence received a show of support in a rally attended by 8,086 of the 16,000 newly elected members of city councils, regional bodies and the republic's parliament, a journalist reported. Only 307 people attended a nearby meeting of a group opposing Latvian independence. In Tokyo, Soviet reformer Yuri Afanasyev condemned his nation's economic sanctions against Lithuania. ``Leaders just want to maintain imperialism,'' said Afanasyev, a legislator who recently split with the Communist Party. But in Vilnius, Andrei N. Girenko, a secretary of the Soviet Communist Party Central Committee, defended the Soviet move and said that Lithuania's declaration of independence meant a loss of preferred prices and favorable trade conditions. ``This would sharply, catastrophically affect the republic's affairs and the living standards of its people,'' he said. Girenko denied Moscow had imposed a total economic boycott, saying that only oil and natural gas were affected. ``This is only a small part of the products that are supplied,'' he said. ``Plans for a total blockade don't exist.'' The streets of Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, were calm Sunday, with people walking rather than using cars as they coped with stringent gasoline rationing that permits about 7 gallons per month for private cars. Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia are all trying to restore the independence they lost in 1940 when they were occupied and forcibly annexed to the Soviet Union. Lithuania has declared independence, Estonia has dropped enforcement of the Soviet Constitution, and Latvia is expected to declare its freedom from the Soviet Union on May 3. Lithuanian Deputy Premier Romualdas Ozolas charged Saturday that the Kremlin was implementing a full economic embargo, halting all rail and truck traffic to the tiny republic. Lithuanian officials also said numerous shipments of food, metals, wood, chemicals and parts had not arrived as scheduled, and payments to Lithuanian businesses have been halted. Ozolas told reporters that Lithuanian ports have already stopped loading goods for exports. On Sunday, the Lithuanian government sent a telegram to Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov saying that the Soviet cut-off of fuel and raw materials would choke Lithuanian processing and manufacturing of goods meant for export and the Soviet market. The republic depends entirely on Soviet resources at subsidized prices. The Soviet decision to cut off all of Lithuania's oil supply and nearly all of its natural gas is expected to put 70 percent of the republic's work force out of work. The Sajudis independence movement also was meeting Sunday. It accused the Kremlin of attempting to use economic means to turn Lithuanians against the drive for independence. ``The Soviet Union seeks to deal a blow to the daily existence of every person, hoping that we shall be overpowered by our material interests,'' the declaration said. Lithuania, the declaration said ``can only be saved through our spiritual fortitude, unity and resolve.'' Also Sunday, Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis appeared on television and denied reports that the declaration of independence would be frozen for two years in hopes of reaching a compromise with Moscow. In Latvia, the 9,000 elected officials meeting in Riga's Daugava Stadium adopted an appeal for the parliament to consider restoring the independence of Latvia ``without delay in its first session,'' journalist Boris Kolesnikov reported. ``The historical experience of the last 50 years convinces us that only a free and independent nation can guarantee the continued existence and development of the Latvian nation, as well as the safety and welfare of all the inhabitants of Latvia,'' the declaration said. In Moscow, about 5,000 people gathered at a pro-democracy rally and shouted, ``Freedom for Lithuania!'' ``Shame on the organizers of the economic blockade of Lithuania!'' read one poster at the demonstration.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Thanks Syria, Reserves Judgment on Iranian Role in Hostage Release
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 23-25, ``In Washington xxx to update with Baker remark and Bush's return to the White House; this lead will stand for the cycle barring unanticpated developments
DOC.TEXT: President Bush welcomed the release of an American hostage Sunday, but declared that ``I don't have forgiveness in my heart as long as one American is held against his will.'' Bush emphasized that the release of Robert Polhill was not enough to warrant a goodwill gesture from him _ other than words of thanks _ toward the kidnappers or the countries they follow. ``I'm not trying to think up any gesture,'' Bush said in response to a question. ``I want all of those hostages out. We're not going to trade.'' Bush learned of Polhill's release while on a daylong fishing expedition in the Florida Keys. He was kept updated by ship-to-shore communications with the White House situation room. As Polhill relished his first day of freedom in 39 months, seven other Americans remained in the captivity of terrorists in Lebanon. ``I can't talk forgiveness,'' Bush said. ``I don't have forgiveness in my heart as long as one American is held against his will and as long as one family has a broken heart.'' He said he talked by telephone with Polhill, his wife and his mother, and that they all noted that other Americans are still hostage. ``This is a mission uncompleted,'' Bush said. Polhill was to be flown to a U.S. military medical facility in Wiesbaden, West Germany for a physical examination. A State Department ``hostage recovery'' team was dispatched to aid Polhill's return to freedom and U.S. officials offered transportation to West Germany for Polhill's family. In a written statement, Bush expressed thanks to Iran and Syria for efforts leading to Polhill's freedom. Iran, particularly, has been a U.S. adversary for more than a decade, and Syria has been denounced as a sponsor of terrorism. However, Bush omitted Iran from his words of appreciation in a later face-to-face meeting with reporters. ``I have goodwill toward Syria for playing an active role in this release,'' he said. As for Iran, he said, he was ``stopping a little short.'' ``I don't want to give credit when I don't know the facts,'' he said. From the day he became president, Bush has been promising that ``goodwill begets goodwill'' an apparent invitation to the kidnappers as well as Syria and Iran to free the Americans. Yet on Sunday, Bush said he was not making any goodwill gesture merely because one hostage, Polhill, was freed. ``I don't go ante up one step and another,'' Bush said. ``I rejoice at this release. ... And I will thank those who facilitated the release and that's exactly the way it's going to stay.'' In his earlier written statement, Bush had said his feeling of satisfaction over Polhill's release was ``substantially tempered'' because other U.S. citizens and Westerners are still in captivity. He said nothing short of the release of all hostages would satisfy him. ``That's the ground rules,'' he said in the statement. ``That's the bottom line.'' Separately, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said: ``We would hope that this release would be the forerunner to the release of others and would pave the way towards the `goodwill begets goodwill' summation at some point. But at this point, with seven hostages still in captivity, the situation has not changed a great deal.'' Bush underscored that any response would await release ``of all the hostages.'' He called hostage-taking ``an immoral practice'' that ``has to stop.'' In Washington, Secretary of State James Baker III reaffirmed the administration's position against making deals for hostages. ``Our policy is that we do not negotiate with hostage-holders and we do not make deals for hostages,'' he said. ``And the reason we don't is because we think that will simply lead to more and more hostage-taking.'' Bush, himself, made no further comments upon his return to the White House Sunday evening. Notwithstanding the administration's posture, Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on the Mideast, said Polhill's release would make it ``appropriate for the United States to send some kind of a gesture that we're willing to enter into a dialogue with Iran.'' And in New York, Kamal Kharazzi, Iran's ambassador to the United Nations, said his government was ``very hopeful that this process would be sped up and more hostages would be released.'' But he said that depends on ``the policies that the other sides would adopt.'' Before Bush spoke directly with reporters, Fitzwater expressed the president's appreciation for whatever roles Iran and Syria played in Polhill's release. ``There were no deals, no negotiations with the hostage takers,'' said Fitzwater. ``We have no way of identifying any specific action on our part that could have been a contributing factor'' to the release. Concerning Iran, which has bedeviled the United States in a string of hostage events over the past 10 years, Fitzwater said: ``We do recognize their role. We do show some gratitude for any help they may have given in this case. We continue to indicate that this is a course of action that does beget good will.'' Bush and Fitzwater both said they did not know whether Iran played a big role in the Polhill release, but Fitzwater said: ``We have always felt that Iran has control or influence over the hostages. We continue to believe that.'' Kharazzi, appearing with Hamilton on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation,'' said the situation was complex, with different groups having different demands holding the hostages. He said Iran does not have influence over all the captors. For days, Syria and Iran had been fueling hopes of an imminent hostage release by the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. The group has held three American educators seized from Beirut University College: Polhill, 55, of New York; Jesse Turner, 42, of Boise, Idaho; and Alann Steen, a native of Boston, who turned 51 Sunday. While expressing pleasure over Polhill's release, Bush said, ``Our satisfaction ... is substantially tempered by the knowledge that seven other innocent Americans, as well as a number of foreign nationals, are still being cruelly held hostage in Lebanon. ``We cannot rest until all hostages are free,'' he said. ``Once again, we urgently call on all parties who hold hostages, or who have any influence, to work to obtain the immediate and unconditional release of the remaining hostages as a humanitarian gesture.'' Among the 18 Western hostages believed held in Lebanon, eight are Americans. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was seized March 16, 1985. Bush has never spelled out how he might reciprocate following the hostages' release. Iran is thought to be interested in obtaining billions of dollars in assets frozen after Americans were taken hostage at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran in 1979. Syria is trying to move back into the Arab mainstream after years of isolation, and apparently is hoping to improve its image in the West.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Fighter Jet Crashes Into Pacific
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian air force jet fighter crashed Sunday into the Pacific Ocean about 18 miles west of Vancouver Island, a military spokeswoman said. The fate of the pilot was unknown. The one-man CF-18 crashed shortly after 2 p.m. PDT, said Maj. Jan Martinsen of the Canadian Forces base in Cold Lake, Alberta. He did not release the pilot's name. The aircraft was on routine training mission with a second CF-18, she said. Search and rescue aircraft from the forces' base in Comox on the British Columbian island were searching for the jet. The fighter is part of the 441 Tactical Fighter Squadron based at CFB Cold Lake. The CF-18 is a version of the American-made F-18 fighter, built by St. Louis-based McDonnell Douglas. The crash was the second involving Canadian Forces F-18s in five days. One pilot was killed and other slighly injured after two of the Canadian jets collided over the West German city of Karlsruhe, showering the city with flaming debris. The jets involved in Tuesday's crash were part of Canada's NATO contingent.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Opens Higher in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold rose 43 cents an ounce on Hong Kong markets Monday, opening at $377.43. It closed at $377 Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Orthodox Party Boosts Shamir's Chances to Form Government
DOC.TEXT: A small ultra-Orthodox party threw its support behind caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on Sunday, boosting his chances of forming a new coalition government, Israel television reported. The television said the spiritual leaders of the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party ordered legislators to back Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc after Shamir pledged to advance the peace process. Also Sunday, an unidentified gunman opened fire at a bus in the occupied West Bank carrying Jewish settlers, slightly wounding the driver in the leg, the army said. Palestinians in the occupied territories, meanwhile, observed a general strike ordered by the uprising's clandestine leadership in support of Christian-Moslem solidarity. But uprising activists in some West Bank towns canceled the strike, which coincided with the Moslem fast month of Ramadan. In clashes throughout the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip four Palestinians were wounded in stone-throwing confrontations with Israeli troops, Arab hospital officials said. Palestine Liberation Organization chief Yasser Arafat has urged Palestinians to refrain from using guns during the uprising, arguing Israel would respond with harsher tactics to end the 28-month-long uprising. Radical Palestinian factions and Moslem fundamentalists have supported the use of firearms. The governing board of Shas reached their decision to support the Likud shortly after Shamir met with the party's spiritual leader, Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, and clarified his stance on the peace process, Israel TV reported. ``Rabbi Yosef and the Torah Sages were convinced by the Prime Minister's desire and by his unequivocal announcement that he will not retreat from the government's peace initiative and his desire to reach peace with our neighbors,'' said Interior Minister Aryeh Deeri, a leading figuire in Shas, said Shamir agreed not to ``retreat from the government's peace initiative and his desire to reach peace with our neighbors.'' The peace initiative calls for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to chose Palestinians to open talks with Israel on an interim peace settlement. Shamir's office said the Prime Minister has not deviated from his long-held position ruling out a PLO role in peace talks. Shamir's rival, Labor Party leader Shimon Peres, has also been trying to put together a new governing coalition since Labor engineered the collapse of the joint government on March 15. The 15-month government fell after the Likud refused to accept a U.S. peace plan, which calls for preliminary negotiations between Israelis and Palestinians. Shas' refusal to support Likud in the no-confidence vote was crucial to the collapse of the coalition government. Both Shamir and Peres have been courting Shas, which holds five seats in Parliament. Shas' decision to back Likud Sunday leaves both major parties in a deadlock, each controlling 60 of Parliament's 120 seats.

DOC.HEAD: Croatia Holds First Free Election, Presidential Runoff In Slovenia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thoughout with reform Communist winning in Slovenia, non-Communists winning in Croatia. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto ZAG1
DOC.TEXT: A reform Communist won a run-off presidential election in Slovenia Sunday and a non-Communist center-right party led in parliamentary elections in the neighboring Yugoslav republic of Croatia. The elections enabled voters in the two republics to choose among Communist reformers and Western-oriented leaders and could further divide the Yugoslav federation. Communist-ruled Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, has accused some leaders in the two republics of being fascist and bent on secession from the Balkan nation of 23 million. With 75 percent of the vote counted in Slovenia, reform Communist Milan Kucan had 57.9 percent of the vote while his opponent, Joze Pucnik, won 42.1 percent Kucan formerly headed the Slovene Communist Party, renamed the Party of Democratic Reform. Pucnik, leader of the five-party DEMOS coalition, has advocated Slovenia's secession from Yugoslavia. In Croatia, where more than 30 parties were entered in the republics first free multiparty elections in 51 years, initial results showed the center-right Croatian Democratic Union leading in 13 out of the first 25 constituencies where counting was under way. It was not clear whether the trend would continue. Croatia's three-chamber Parliament has 356 seats. The reformist Communist Party was second with a lead in 10 constituencies, and the middle-of-the-road Coalition of National Accord led in two districts. Sunday's balloting was for the 116-seat Chamber of Counties and the 80-seat Socio-Political Chamber. An additional vote was to be held Monday for 160 seats in the Labour Chamber. Some 2,000 supporters of the Croatian Democratic Union gathered in the Zagreb electoral district of Dubrava, the home of party leader Franjo Tudjman, to celebrate what they described as ``the victory of the Croatian people.'' ``I am convinced we will win an absolute majority and the Union will form Croatia's first non-Communist administration,'' Tudjman said. A second round of voting will be held in two weeks in constituencies where no candidate won a majority. Despite Pucnik's loss in Slovenia, DEMOS will form the first non-Communist government in any of Yugoslavia's six republics in 45 years. Two weeks ago, it won 55 percent of the seats in Slovenia's regional legislature in the first round of elections. Kucan and Pucnik emerged as front-runners from first-round voting when Kucan received 44.6 percent of the vote and Pucnik 26.6 percent. A total of 1.4 million Slovenians of a population of about 2 million were eligible to vote. Yugoslavia's last multiparty elections were held in 1939. Opposition groups claim that a ballot in 1945 was rigged by the Communist Party, which thereafter banned all dissent and turned the country into a single-party state. The leader of the triumphant Croatian party, Tudjman, says his party favors a confederation in which all of Yugoslavia's six republics would have ``full sovereign rights.'' It is not bent on secession, he said, denying the accusations from Serbia. Following its victory in the first round of the Slovenian elections, DEMOS has also softened its stand on independence. Since the death in 1980 of Josip Broz Tito, the strong-willed founder of communist Yugoslavia, a nine-person rotating presidency representing the country's diverse ethnic makeup has headed the country, under the guidance of the Communist Party. But ethnic conflict and political dissent persist. Two other Yugoslav republics, Bosnia and Macedonia, have allowed formation of opposition parties and are expected to schedule free elections soon. But in Serbia, the largest constituent republic, and the smallest region of Montenegro, the ruling Communists have yet to formally legalize independent parties.

DOC.HEAD: Volcano Claims Two More Homes
DOC.TEXT: Lava oozed through this rural coastal community Sunday, destroying two homes and menacing several others. The first home in the Kalapana Gardens subdivision burned to the ground about 5 a.m., and the second caught fire just after 9 a.m., said Lanny Nakano, spokesman for Hawaii County Civil Defense. ``This is something. There's no sign of this thing stopping,'' Nakano said. ``The lava just keeps coming.'' The lava flow from Kilauea Volcano on Hawaii Island has destroyed nine homes since Wednesday, 13 in April and 89 since the current eruption started more than seven years ago. Kilauea Volcano began erupting Jan. 3, 1983, and has caused in excess of $20 million in damage.

DOC.HEAD: 4,000 Teens March at Auschwitz in Remembrance of Holocaust
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th pvs, `Dandelions waved...' with one graf to CORRECT spelling of kaddish. Pick up 8th pvs, `Television cameras...'
DOC.TEXT: Four thousand teen-agers from 36 countries, carrying the memories of 6 million Jews killed by the Nazis, made a ``March of the Living'' Sunday from the Auschwitz concentration camp to the crematoria of Birkenau. Writer Elie Wiesel, diplomats and Israeli parliamentarians joined the young marchers for the two-mile walk marking Holocaust Memorial Day. The march at the camp in southern Poland was in memory of those who died in Nazi death camps as well as in the Warsaw ghetto uprising that began April 19, 1943. The sunny day turned eerily cloudy and light rain started as Wiesel stood at a podium before a gray stone monument to recall his youth at Auschwitz: ``I see them, forever I see them. ... Years and years ago I saw, I cannot tell you what I saw. I'm afraid that if I told you we would all wake up in tears and would not be able to stop. I see a young girl ... ,'' he said before stopping, apparently unable to continue, and silently leaving the podium. Many cried as the students, all wearing blue shirts, some carrying Israeli flags and others bouquets of flowers, walked along the train tracks that ended at the cremetoria. Dandelions waved in the wind-swept grass now covering the rubble of the camp. Torches were lighted, poems read and mournful violin songs played before a reading of the kaddish, a Jewish prayer for the dead. Television cameras positioned in former Nazi watchtowers broadcast live to Israel, where solemn Holocaust remembrance events were under way. As the march began, Galia Haber, a Jerusalem high school student, recalled seeing the number the Nazis tattoed on her grandmother's arm at Auschwitz. ``I remember when I saw her I thought of a supermarket with numbered goods and I thought, did somebody buy her? ... It's very sad to think that my grandmother, whom I love so much ... once was just a number,'' she told Israeli radio, which broadcast the march live. Shawn Tepper, 17, of Miami Beach, Fla, held hands with a row of other young American Jews and said the experience was overwhelming but ``proved to everyone that we are alive, we are together and we are strong.'' Sunday's event was the second ``March of the Living.'' Participants said it had special significance because of the drive toward German unification and Israel's rapid renewal of ties with Eastern European countries that once had flourishing Jewish communities. The Nazis built the Auschwitz complex in southern Poland as the main engine of Hitler's ``Final Solution.'' Estimates of the death count vary, but recent research has put the toll at about 1.5 million, more than 90 percent Jews. There were 1,500 participants in the first ``March of the Living,'' held in 1988 to mark the 45th anniversary of the Warsaw ghetto uprising. In the battle, several hundred Jewish insurgents staged a desperate three-week struggle against the Nazi drive to liquidate the last 75,000 inhabitants of the walled ghetto. U.S. and Israeli organizers plan to hold the march every two years. About 3 million Polish Jews perished during World War II. Most of the approximately 500,000 who survived from the prewar population subsequently emigrated, many during an anti-Semitic purge in 1968, and there are now only several thousand Jews in Poland.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Foreign Minister: Normalization Would Benefit Asia
DOC.TEXT: Vietnam's Foreign Minister says normalizing diplomatic relations between his country and the United States could contribute to peace in Southeast Asia. The official, Nguyen Co Thach, said in an interview in this week's Time magazine that Vietnam has met all the requirements set by the U.S. government for improving relations. They include agreements on accounting for military personnel missing in action in the war in Vietnam, reunification of Vietnamese families and human rights abuses in re-education camps. ``But in the State Department there is no change'' toward Vietnam, he complained. ``Normal relations between the U.S. and Vietnam could contribute to peace and cooperation in Southeast Asia and to maintaining the independence of this area vis-a-vis China,'' Thach said during the interview which was conducted in Hanoi. He said the United States was using Vietnam's continued military presence in neighboring Cambodia as an excuse to avoid normalizing relations with his country. ``The Cambodian problem serves only as a pretext,'' Thatch said. ``The greatest mistake of the U.S. is not the Vietnam War. It is this strategy of using Vietnam as a pawn in the relationship between China and the U.S. ``It is time to heal the wounds of war,'' he said. ``I don't mention the physical or the mental wounds, but the moral ones. As long as this state of abnormal relations drag on, the moral wounds will bleed.'' According to a Time-CNN poll, 48 percent of the U.S. public and 44 percent of Vietnam veterans feel the time has come to re-establish diplomatic relations with Vietnam. The poll, also in this week's Time, indicated that 58 percent of Vietnam veterans believe that the U.S. was right to get involved in the war, while 32 percent believe it was wrong. Only 29 percent of the general public approves of the role the United States played in Vietnam, and 57 percent disapproves. Sixty-one percent of the veterans said they are proud of their role in the war, while 28 percent said they felt no pride. Among the general public, 39 percent were proud of the U.S. role and 48 percent were not. The poll of 1,000 adults was conducted on April 9-10. The margin of error is plus or minus 3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Premier Leaves For Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng left Monday for the first visit in 26 years by a Chinese head of government to the Soviet Union, China's longtime rival for leadership of the Communist world. Li's four-day trip is intended to promote normal, friendly relations and an easing of border tensions at a time when both countries are focused on serious internal problems. The official Chinese press hailed Li's trip as being of ``profound significance'' to peace in Asia and the world. But it is expected to have few concrete effects on a relationship that has slowly improved in recent years after decades of mistrust. The 61-year-old premier is to hold at least two rounds of talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who in May made the first visit by a Soviet leader to Beijing in three decades. Gorbachev's historic visit was overshadowed by huge student-led democracy demonstrations in Beijing, which ended weeks later when Li and other hard-line Chinese leaders brought in troops to crush the movement. The two sides are expected to sign an agreement on fostering trade and will lay down guiding principles on easing military confrontation along their 4,350-mile frontier. Progress is unlikely on territorial disputes or cutbacks in the 500,000 Soviet soldiers and more than 1 million Chinese troops along the border. China and the Soviet Union split over ideological differences in 1960 and fought a brief border war in 1969. In 1972 China restored relations with the United States, in part because then leader Mao Tse-tung saw the Soviet Union as China's most serious military threat. Western diplomats say improved relations with Moscow do not mean China can play a ``Soviet card'' against the United States as Sino-U.S. relations deteriorate over human-rights issues. China has stressed it will never be a Soviet ally as it was in the 1950s, and China's inherent suspicions of Soviet aims have grown with Gorbachev's reform policies. The ideological hard-liners who now rule China reportedly blame Gorbachev for the fall of Communist parties in East Europe and see his program of perestroika as leading to the demise of socialism.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explodes at Dance, One Killed, 40 Injured
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded during a charity dance in a town just north of San Salvador, killing one person and injuring 40 people, a Red Cross spokesman said Sunday. Fourteen of the injured in the explosion at a home in El Sitio late Saturday were taken to hospitals for treatment, the spokesman, Carlos Lopez Mendoza, said. He said the dance was held to collect funds to build a church. El Sitio is near Apopa, seven miles north of the capital. ``Witnesses say that suddenly at 11 p.m. they heard a loud explosion,'' Lopez Mendoza said. He did not know how many people were attending the dance. There was no immediate indication of who threw or placed the explosives or of what type were used, he said. The armed forces press office said it had no information on the case. Earlier Saturday, an economics professor was killed in the capital when a bomb exploded in his car as he was leaving the University of El Salvador. No suspects had been identified in the attack on Randolfo Tejada, who also was director of the Salvadoran Institute for Rehabilitation of the Disabled, a police spokesman said. There was no claim of responsibility for that attack. Right-wing death squads have targeted academics and religious activists during the decade-old civil war between leftist guerrillas and a succession of U.S.-backed governments. More than 71,000 people have been killed, most of them civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Army Turns Over Base to U.N. Observers
DOC.TEXT: The Sandinista army turned over an eastern military base to U.N. observers Sunday, and the first contingent of U.N. troops rolled into Nicaragua to enforce Contra demobilization and disarmament. An accord signed Thursday by the Contras, the outgoing Sandinista government and representatives of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro requires a cease-fire verified by the United Nations in seven security zones set up for demobilization. Mrs. Chamorro takes office Wednesday, ending the decade-old rule of the leftist Sandinistas. About 2,400 Contra rebels began arriving at Los Chinamos near El Ayote in the Fourth Security Zone Sunday, one hour after Sandinista Mayor Bayardo Rodriguez turned over the El Ayote base to U.N. forces. The mountainous security zone 175 miles east of the capital of Managua encompasses El Ayote, Los Chinamos and three other towns. Sandinista troups moved to bases more than 40 miles away from the security zone. The cease-fire accord requires they relocate at least 12 miles away. A 15-vehicle caravan of about 170 U.N. troops from Venezuela rolled across the Honduras border into Nicaragua at Las Manos, 156 miles north of Managua, Sunday, destined for the First Security Zone. U.N. troops are scheduled to begin disarming Contras on Wednesday in the first, second and third security zones, U.N. spokeswoman Angelica Hunt said in an interview. A contingent of 193 Venezuelan soldiers arrived in Tegucigalpa, the capital of Honduras, to the north of Nicaragua Sunday to join a 700-member U.N. battalion supervising the Contra demobilization in Honduras and Nicaragua. The contingent is scheduled to enter Nicaragua Monday to supervise disarmament in the second and third security zones, Hunt said. About 30,000 people, mostly civilians, died in the 9-year-old Nicaraguan war.

DOC.HEAD: Polhill Being Bombarded with Sensations, Emotions, Former Hostage Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT that Schaefer has spoken to 250,000 students.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Robert Polhill is being bombarded by sensations and emotions after more than three years of captivity in Lebanon, and faces physical and mental challenges in the coming months, former hostages said after his release Sunday. ``Bob Polhill probably only learned he was gonna be released about two hours ago,'' former hostage David Jacobsen said Sunday afternoon. Polhill, 55, of New York was freed in Beirut nearly 39 months after he and two other Americans were abducted from Beirut University College on Jan. 24, 1987. He taken to Wiesbaden, West Germany, for debriefing and a medical examination. Polhill will have to grapple with guilt, said retired Air Force Col. Thomas E. Schaefer, one of the 52 Americans held hostage for 444 days in Iran. ``One of the major things he'll feel is: `Why did they let me go?,''' Schaefer said. ``And the first thing I would tell him is to, `Don't let it bother you,' because those guilt feelings are not substantiated.'' In a telephone interview from Peoria, Ariz., Schaefer said that on his release in January 1981 he felt guilty that he'd been captured and had put his family, the nation and the Air Force through such an ordeal. After Schaefer was freed, he opened an agency to help people deal with stress and adversity. Schaefer, 59, said Polhill will probably spend the next few days physically recovering from his ordeal, then try to regain some semblance of order in his life. He said Polhill will have to deal with changes in the world, his loved ones and himself since he was taken captive. ``He'll get the best professional help in the world in Wiesbaden. And he will have access to whatever assistance he may need,'' Schaefer said. Jacobsen, who was held in West Beirut from May 1985 to November 1986, said in a CBS News interview: ``I'm reliving my release and the emotions of it. ``In the hour drive to Damascus from West Beirut, it's been the first time he's been able to use all his senses to see more than 10 feet away; it's probably the first time he's been out of doors in three years. He's been held in a little basement dungeon most of that time,'' Jacobsen said. ``He's being bombarded. He's seing the stars, he's seeing people, he's hearing noises, he's smelling the breeze, and everything,'' the former hostage said. ``He is going to be thinking about his friends who remain behind, wishing that they could be sharing that moment,'' Jacobsen said. ``He's going to be very concerned that he says nothing that in any way would jeopardize the welfare of his friends.'' In an interview later with Syrian television, Polhill said he was ``happy and grateful'' to people who worked on his case, but remained deeply concerned about fellow captives Alann Steen and Jesse Turner. Polhill was being taken to Wiesbaden, West Germany, for debriefing and a medical examination, U.S. officials said. Schaefer said Polhill's next step will probably be dealing with the press and requests to speak. ``It can be overpowering; he'll get thousands of requests,'' Schaefer said. ``He has to learn to say, `No.''' Schaefer credited his own recovery to the hostage reception team and his wife, Anita. He said it took him several months to get over his ordeal, and that for weeks after his release he would wake up screaming in the middle of the night. ``It took me several months just to get used to crowds,'' he said. Schaefer now requently speaks to groups, and said he has spoken before about 250,000 students since his release.

DOC.HEAD: Historian: Johnson Didn't Steal Election; Others Did
DOC.TEXT: Lyndon Johnson didn't steal the 1948 Senate election, as a recent biography contends, but a political boss might have rigged the election to get Johnson's opponent, says a close Johnson associate. Joe B. Frantz, now a history professor, contends the election was stolen for Johnson, possibly without his knowledge, by a disgruntled south Texas political boss eager to derail the opponent, Coke Stevenson. Johnson won the election by 87 votes out of almost a million cast, collecting 99 percent of the south Texas vote. ``There's no question the election was stolen,'' Frantz said, but he contends that political boss George Parr filched it to spite Stevenson, not necessarily to help Johnson. Frantz said he revealed the information at a recent historical society banquet because of accusations against Johnson by Robert A. Caro in ``Means of Ascent,'' the second volume in Caro's biography of Johnson. Frantz, a White House aide under Johson and former chairman of the University of Texas history department, teaches at Corpus Christi State University. Frantz put together the Oral History Project for the Johnson Presidential Library in Austin, taping interviews with nearly 1,000 people, including Johnson's political enemies. He said his information about Parr's political vendetta against Stevenson came from an interview he conducted with Stevenson when the former governor was in his 80s. Stevenson died in 1975 at age 87. ``It would have been in the early 1970s,'' Frantz told The Associated Press. ``He set me down and he said, `I'm going to give you the straight story' ...'' Stevenson and Parr had always been close allies, Stevenson told Frantz, until Parr asked Stevenson, then governor, to name a certain man judge at Laredo. Stevenson refused because ``the fellow was an absolute rascal and into evey sort of political sin available,'' Frantz said. Parr promised revenge, the professor said. ``The feeling is that Parr decided, `I'm going to teach Coke Stevenson a lesson and, at the same time, get in very good with the new senator from Texas,''' Frantz said. Frantz was unable to locate Parr to interview him before Parr died in the mid-1970s. Frantz said he interviewed the man responsible for disposing of votes from a contested box before a recount could be held. He said he came away from the encounter convinced the south Texans were guilty of stuffing the box, which disappeared after the count, with illegal votes. ``They were a bunch of rascals,'' he said. Frantz said he thought Caro's characterization of Johnson in his first volume, ``The Path to Power,'' was slanted against his subject. He said that he felt that in the second book Caro expressed annoyance ``as if Johnson had pulled off the dirtiest steal in history. He doesn't see things in the context of the times.'' ``We didn't know what a secret ballot was,'' Frantz said. ``I grew up in Weatherford, and all the precincts used to vote in the same room in the courthouse and all the courthouse hangers-on would stand around and watch you.'' It was not at all unusual for campaigners to know how a vote was going before balloting ended, he said, and for people to round up votes midway through the voting to counteract trends. ``I was sort of amused by Robert Caro's almost innocence in how dirty all this was,'' said Frantz, former director of the Texas State Historical Association. ``When the national press seized on it, it's like he expected some sort of local paradox down here. Actually it's no dirtier than anywhere else.''

DOC.HEAD: Crowds Gather To Mourn Civil Rights Leader Ralph Abernathy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with quotes Jesse Jackson, Andrew Young, others. Pick up 9th graf, `Abernathy, who...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AX2
DOC.TEXT: In the church where he preached for 30 years, the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy was mourned Sunday by civil rights leaders and citizens as a man ``high up on the honor roll'' of the battle for racial equality. About 300 people lined up Sunday afternoon after the regular service at the West Hunter Street Baptist Church, where the civil rights leader was pastor from 1961 until his death last week at age 64. The Rev. Jesse Jackson, Martin Luther King III, and former Atlanta Mayor Andrew Young and Robert F. Kennedy Jr. were among those mourning the man who marched and worked beside the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. in the 1960s, but who angered many activists with an autobiography they feel belittled King's memory. ``And the Walls Came Tumbling Down,'' published last year, described King as having liaisons with women the night he was assassinated in 1968. Many of those who criticized the book have since Abernathy's death focused on his work helping King build the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and pressing the case of equal rights for blacks. At an evening memorial service, Abernathy's son, Kwame, told the congregation his father was a ``truly selfless leader.'' ```Abide in love' was one of the last things my daddy said,'' the younger Abernathy recalled. Jackson and Young, who worked with Abernathy and King in the 1960s, did not speak to the crowd, but embraced on the podium above the casket. After the service, Young, a candidate for Georgia governor, said Abernathy's sacrifices helped make Young's political successes possible. ``I've never forgotten that and I won't ever forget it,'' Young said. Jackson said Abernathy's death means a time ``for pause and reflection'' among King's former aides. ``All of us have a profound sense of loss,'' Jackson said. ``We must judge him on what he meant to our struggle and he was high up on the honor roll.'' The Rev. Robert G. Grant, president of the American Freedom Coalition in Washington, commented on the epitaph Abernathy's wrote for himself: ``I tried,'' Grant said, ``Yes, Ralph, you did try. You tried to bring your people those normal things of life that most people take for granted.'' Abernathy, who was King's closest friend and advisor, died April 17 of a heart attack induced by a blood clot. Funeral services are scheduled for noon Monday at West Hunter. Most of those who lined up early either were members of Abernathy's church or residents of the neighborhood. The mourners, some of whom carried children, walked quietly past the coffin, and several touched the sleeves of his white minister's robe. Family members viewed Abernathy's body privately, then left the church. One of Abernathy's daughters, Donzaleigh Abernathy Bosley, arranged flowers around her father's open casket, and placed a single red rose in his left hand. ``She won't leave him,'' a church aide whispered to another. Ethel Bell, 83, a member of West Hunter since 1932, said Abernathy hinted during a February sermon that he expected to die. ``He said he had really enjoyed being pastor,'' she said. ``He said he wanted us to always get along. That tells you something.'' Morning services were sad, but proceeded as usual, said church member Juanita H. Gardner. ``Every now and then there was a cry out of sadness,'' she said. ``It's a little sadder; that's to be expected.''

Millions of Americans gathered in parks and on village greens Sunday to celebrate a worldwide 20th anniversary party for Earth Day, the environmental ``teach-in'' that launched a movement. Thousands watched a hot-air balloon decorated as the Earth rise in New York's Times Square where the ball falls on New Year's Eve. Students at Susquehanna University in Pennsylvania buried a paper mache ``Old Earth'' containing a plastic foam cup, aerosol can, disposable diaper and container of leaded gasoline. In all, an estimated 3,600 American cities and towns mustered forces to rejuvenate the environmental movement, born with the original Earth Day in 1970. ``I get a real sense of a renewal, and a kind of rededication, that will provide the support for change at the grass-roots level,'' said John McLachlan, scientific director at the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences in Research Triangle Park, N.C. ``There's a sense of urgency that hasn't been there.''

A top Communist official from Moscow said Sunday the Lithuanian independence movement is leading the republic to catastrophe, and denied the Kremlin has imposed a total economic blockade. The Sajudis independence movement, whose leaders dominate Lithuania's government, declared its determination to stand by the March 11 declaration of independence. In neighboring Latvia, meanwhile, the drive for independence received a show of support in a rally attended by 9,000 newly elected members of city councils, regional bodies and the republic's parliament, a journalist reported. The streets of Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, were calm, with people walking rather than using cars as they coped with stringent gasoline rationing that permits about 7 gallons per month for private cars.

Nigeria's military government said it had crushed a coup attempt Sunday after heavy fighting with rebel troops for control of the capital of Lagos. The rebellion in Africa's most populous nation was launched by middle-ranking officers opposed to President Gen. Ibrahim Babangida. The rebels said they wanted to break up Nigeria's federation of 19 states to end Moslem domination. ``The unfortunate situation in Lagos this morning has been brought under control,'' Babangida told reporters Sunday night. The general said the fighting had been heavy and his aide, Lt. Col. U. K. Bello, was among those killed during a gunbattle at the military headquarters in Lagos, the official News Agency of Nigeria reported.

Real estate problems are spreading from the Southwest and Northeast, threatening metropolitan markets across the nation, according to a new statistical analysis by banking regulators. Banks in regions already beset with falling or flat real estate prices have responded by tightening their lending policies. An analysis by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. shows that lenders elsewhere also may have reason for concern. The FDIC, which insures bank and savings and loan deposits up to $100,000, has fashioned what it hopes will be an early warning system that identifies soft real estate markets before they turn sour. A preliminary version released last week examined commercial real estate in 40 metropolitan areas. Some well-known sore spots in the Southwest ranked high on the list. Phoenix, Ariz.; was first, Austin, Texas, was sixth and Oklahoma City was seventh.

It was like a journey back in time when the National AIDS Commission traveled to south Georgia last week for a firsthand look at how rural areas are coping with the deadly disease. ``I'm afraid we're seeing history repeat itself,'' said Dr. June Osborn, chairwoman of the panel, after the commission spent two days in Waycross, Albany and Macon visiting with AIDS patients and talking with health care professionals. ``The same fear, the same isolation for people with AIDS, the same difficulty in mobilizing coordinated care that we saw in the beginning of the urban epidemic back a few years ago is happening all over again,'' she said. The commission's trip came on the heels of a federal Centers for Disease Control report that AIDS is spreading more rapidly in rural areas than in cities. From 1988 to 1989, the CDC found that nonmetropolitan areas had a 37 percent increase in new AIDS cases while metro areas had only a 5 percent gain.

DOC.HEAD: Market That Transcends Europe's Borders Remains Out of Reach
Graphic in AP Access under EUROSTOCK
DOC.TEXT: The pan-European stock market is proving an elusive dream. Europe's major exchanges agree there should be one market in the big European stocks, to provide greater liquidity and efficiency. But they disagree over how to create it. The efforts have been slow, piecemeal, and contradictory. This is increasingly helping London's aggressive International Stock Exchange dominate the European financial centers. Europe has 39 national and major regional stock exchanges trading about 300 major European stocks. Fragmented, structurally diverse, they not only compete with each other but with less formal trading systems comprised of telephone links and computerized videoscreen networks. Moreover, they soon will face competition from the National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotations, also known as NASDAQ. The American screen-based, over-the-counter market plans to begin operating during European hours in the third quarter of this year. The demand for a pan-European market comes from big international institutional investors, who want to trade in Europe's stocks in a single market in the European time zone. Andrew Hugh Smith, chairman of London's exchange, a year ago said the answer was a Europe-wide screen-based trading system, which London already has. Addressing a conference in Frankfurt last month, Hugh Smith proposed a joint initiative by London and the German Federation of Stock Exchanges as ``the critical mass, the focus, upon which a truly European market could be built.'' Regis Rousselle, head of the Paris exchange, has suggested creating a Single European List of 300 major stocks that could be traded on any exchange. The Federation of European Community Stock Exchanges, meanwhile, is planning ``le Pipe,'' a system to provide European stock prices and company information. A single network will transmit data prepared by the 12 Common Market exchanges, and it might develop into a trading system. The major investment firms increasingly are engaging in informal pan-European trading through their own computerized video-screens, away from the exchanges. But this leaves investors less protected because there's less surveillance to detect cheating and irregularities. Europe's exchanges have talked for decades about cooperating, and it was hoped action would replace words with the approach of 1992, when the EEC theoretically becomes a barrier-free marketplace of 320 million consumers. But Stewart Gilchrist, a director of Scottish Amicable Investment Managers, a Glasgow-based institutional investor, said: ``I don't think we are particularly optimistic...'' Frank Lewis, executive director of European trading at Shearson Lehman Hutton International Inc. in London, said a pan-European market was an impractical ideal. ``Every local market is always going to fight to maintain their local autonomy and their individuality,'' Lewis said. ``There's also a hesitancy on the part of the customers.'' For instance, someone investing in Portugal is likely to believe that a Portuguese broker is the best-qualified to offer advice, Lewis said. ``That is the perception and is to a large degree true and can be overcome, but it's an uphill battle.'' London's exchange has used a screen-based system called SEAQ International for five years, enabling it to win business from other European exchanges and develop substantial trade in international shares. It also benefits from being English-speaking and better established than its continental counterparts. Hugh Smith estimated that about one-fifth of West German stock trading takes place in London, where trade in non-British shares grew to $50.5 billion in February from $41 billion in September. London accounted for 35 percent of Europe's total market capitalization of $1.8 trillion at the end of 1988, figures provided by London's exchange show. Germany came in second, with 13 percent, and France, third, with 11.5 percent. The market capitalization figure represents the total value of all domestic shares listed on the major exchanges. West Germany is fighting back by modernizing. Last year it launched a screen-based reporting system called IBIS, which provides prices in blue-chip stocks to the country's eight exchanges. One hurdle to harmonization is the wide differences in the way the exchanges make the final swap of cash for shares, known as the clearing and settlement process. The exchanges face competition from private companies operating as clearing houses. Britain's system is among the worst, piling up huge backlogs. To remedy this, London's exchange will start operating a paperless settlement system called Taurus in October 1991. London's trading is ``quote-driven,'' with many market makers competing for business by offering the best price. They have abandoned the exchange floor for screens and phones in their offices. But this method has generated such fierce competition that it has driven many market makers out of the British equities business. The sluggish volume following the October 1987 stock market crash hasn't helped. Other major exchanges are ``order-driven,'' with buyers and sellers matched at a central point by market makers known as specialists. Their role is similar to that of New York Stock Exchange specialists, who are entrusted with the responsibility of keeping markets orderly, partly through buying and selling shares from their own inventories. The weakness of the Continent's trading centers became evident during the near-crash last October. Many of the exchanges shut down when they couldn't handle the flood of sell orders. Many European exchanges _ not London _ also have ``circuit breakers'' which limit how far shares can fluctuate in a session. Europe's exchanges have scrambled to modernize and deregulate in recent years. The growth of competition in the 1980s has broken down many clubby cartels with their fixed, high commissions and webs of regulations. Britain led with ``Big Bang,'' the sweeping 1986 deregulation that allowed foreign firms and commercial banks to deal in securities and permitted more participants to make markets in stocks.

DOC.HEAD: Stockholders To Vote on Getting Out of Tobacco Business
DOC.TEXT: If a Catholic priest from New York has his way, Philip Morris Cos. will stop making and selling cigarettes by the year 2000. The Rev. Michael Crosby successed in getting a no-cigarettes resolution introduced at the 1990 annual meeting of the maker of Marlboros after two years of failed legal attempts. Shareholders will vote on the issue Thursday during the New York-based food and tobacco company's annual meeting in Richmond. ``We know the cards are stacked against us,'' said Crosby, who coordinates the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility in New York. Not surprisingly, management of the multi-billion-dollar company is urging stockholders to vote against the resolution, which is included in Philip Morris' proxy statement. ``The cigarette business is the company's original core business. It has been and remains an important and lawful business,'' management's statement said. ``It is a major contributor to the company's profitability,'' the company said. ``The board believes that the proposal is ill-conceived and would be highly detrimental to the company.'' In 1989, $17.9 billion, or 39 percent, of Philip Morris' $44.8 billion in revenue came from domestic and foreign tobacco operations. The rest came from the company's interest in beer, food, real estate and financial services. Philip Morris has moved away from tobacco and into other businesses with its purchases of Kraft and General Foods, which together form the largest food company in the United States and Canada. Philip Morris, which operates a cigarette factory in Richmond, has 11 percent of the world market for cigarettes. Its Marlboro brand is the world's best-selling consumer packaged product. Crosby's proposal is not the only anti-smoking shareholder issue before tobacco companies this year. American Brands Inc., for example, faces a similar measure that would force the Old Greenwich, Conn., company to get out of the tobacco business. Crosby's proposal also is not the only one attacking Philip Morris and its tobacco business. Another is aimed at preventing the sale of cigarettes to children, or the promotion of them for children. The Evangelical Lutheran Church in America secured that item on the agenda, and Philip Morris management also opposes it. ``The purpose of the company's cigarette advertising and promotional activities is to persuade smokers to purchase our brands rather than those marketed by our competitors,'' the company said in its proxy. ``These activities are not directed to minors; nor are they intended to induce anyone to smoke.'' While the proposals are unlikely to succeed, they are designed to draw attention to health problems associated with smoking, said Crosby, who will get five minutes during the meeting to discuss his measure. Crosby hopes to get at least 3 percent of the about 925.6 million outstanding shares on a ``smoke-free'' Philip Morris. Under federal rules, that would get the issue on next year's ballot without a legal fight.

DOC.HEAD: Software Maker Plans To Add 1,000 Workers
DOC.TEXT: Software publisher Microsoft Corp. said it plans to add at least 1,000 employees this year, increasing its worldwide employment by about one-fifth. Microsoft, the nation's largest producer of personal computer software, has 4,800 employees worldwide, including 2,600 at its Redmond headquarters outside Seattle. Most of the new employees will be software engineers and technical personnel at the headquarters, Microsoft administration director Raymond Ferguson said. Ferguson said Microsoft wants to add about 1,000 workers annually to keep up with rapid growth. He also said the company plans to add two, 160,000-square-foot buildings to its 800,000-square-foot headquarters. Microsoft has 16 offices in the United States and 22 others worldwide. Microsoft's profits rose 83 percent to $310.9 million in the quarter ended March 31, while revenue climbed 45 percent to $846.5 million. Sales in the past year topped $1 billion for the first time.
